PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the senators in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life of all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That in 1987-88 the Federal Government paid $6.4 million from taxpayers funds for 61,879 abortions under Medicare Items 6469 and 274/275 alone.
That in the same year Federal Government grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies and abolish Government funding of abortion.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Chaney (from 69 citizens) and Jones (from nine citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament.

That we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.

Halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park and;

Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The Hawke Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill concerning Credit Reference Reporting will

(1) Prohibit many legitimate uses of credit information by organisations such as insurance companies, real estate agents, businesses selling goods on credit, and companies renting or leasing goods and equipment.
(2) Add to the cost of business and increase interest rates, and insurance charges and lead to over commitment by borrowers.

Reject Labor Government's Privacy Amendment Bill to enable business to have access to credit information they require to make sensible commercial decisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: End of War List
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned showeth that:
The members of the Australian Armed Forces who served in Vietnam from 1962 to 1973 did so with distinction, valour and professionalism, upholding the traditions of the Armed Forces.
After World War 2 and the Korean War the Australian Government approved an End of War List of Gallantry Medals for individual acts of bravery that were not rewarded during wartime.
The Whitlam Government refused to approve such an End of War List at the end of the Vietnam War.
Your humble petitioners pray that
The Federal Government reverse the decision of the Whitlam Government and thus approve an End of War List for the Australian Armed Forces personnel that served in Vietnam.
Upon the approval of the End of War List, the case of 2nd Lieutenant John Fraser, 3RAR be considered for the award of a posthumous military honour.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Peace Tax Fund
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully brings to your attention:
that there are individuals who have a conscientious objection to war because of their religious or general moral principles
and that the Parliament of this country has already recognised the right of such individuals not to have to participate in military service in time of war
and that all Australian taxpayers are required to contribute to military expenditure, regardless of their beliefs, through that part of their tax that is used for the Defence budget

and that while we acknowledge the right of the Government to levy taxes and to decide on the expenditure of monies so collected we cannot accept that those with a conscientious objection to war should be forced to contribute to military expenditure
Your petitioners therefore pray

that the Federal Government will acknowledge the right of those who have a conscientious objection to war to withhold their taxes from military allocations and enable the military related proportion of their taxes to be used for peaceful purposes only

and, as we note that taxes are collected or disbursed for specific purposes (such as for Medicare), that the Commissioner of Taxation be directed that the military-related proportion of taxes collected from conscientious objectors to war be set aside in a separate fund, the Peace Tax Fund, to be used only for peaceful purposes, such purposes to be determined by the Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —In directing a question to the Minister for Finance, I refer to the front page article of today's Sydney Morning Herald in which the Minister for Social Security is quoted as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: In April this year you got the largest tax cuts in history. Massive. $5.8 billion . . .
And probably in a tax-wage trade-off next year you'll get something of the same order. All paid for.

If we set aside that part of any such tax cuts which merely involves returning to taxpayers the proceeds of bracket creep during the current financial year, I ask the Minister how the remaining roughly $3 1/2 billion of such tax cuts will be financed. Will the Minister give an assurance that full details of the required $3 1/2 billion offsetting expenditure cuts will be given at the time of any such announcement? If not, by how much does the Government intend to run down the prospective Budget surplus, that is, relax fiscal policy?

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't squib it.
—Fancy them calling anyone a squib.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is exactly what I was going to say, Senator Collins. Fancy anybody on the other side of the House having the effrontery to call anybody else a squib. Who were the squibs? Who left government with a prospective Budget deficit of $10 billion, 5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), as Senator Stone told them at the time? Who are the squibs? There were five Howard Budgets in which outlays exceeded the Budget estimate every year-a Budget deficit every year.
—Order! There are too many interjections. I ask the Minister not to reply to them.

—Very well, Mr President. Any suggestion that this Government needs to enter into a shabby bidding duel on tax cuts is, of course, clearly ridiculous. The Opposition tried that one back in 1987 when it came in and said that it would give everybody $50 or $60 a week in tax cuts. I have forgotten what the exact tax cuts were. One of the Opposition's former, more rational and more honest colleagues, the former member for Moore, had previously written that any party that promises tax cuts-this was in the 1987 context-in excess of a few dollars a week should not be believed. The Opposition tried that then, and it did not work then. It is trying a variant of that now, and it does not work now.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that the Government does not have under consideration a wage-tax trade-off for next year. The Treasurer has said that the Government will have no hesitation in increasing further the surplus in the next Budget if it is necessary to lower interest rates and keep the investment surge going. Of course, we will not overcome our trade difficulties unless that sort of thing happens.

In response to the earlier part of Senator Stone's question, in the last Budget the Government delivered $25 to $30 a week to families with children, at the same time as we delivered the biggest Budget surplus in history. Of course, there are not too many Budget surpluses in history; in fact, there are only two to date, and the third and biggest one is looming up this year. As for Senator Alston talking about who are and are not the wimps, the Liberal and National parties, which governed this country for 30 years after the Second World War, did not produce a Budget surplus in any year, and were ignominiously kicked out of office in 1983 with a Budget deficit of $10 billion or 5 per cent of gross domestic product. If one converts that into current values, that is about a $17 billion Budget deficit as a proportion of GDP. That is what the wimps opposite left behind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his reiteration of the Treasurer's recent statement that the Government has no intention of entering into a shabby auction. I thank him also for his assurance that the Government has no intention of taking the route of providing tax cuts through unfunded reductions in the Budget surplus. In that case, and having in mind Mr Howe's statement yesterday that `we are sitting on an $8 billion surplus and it is not as if we are not able to deliver', will the Minister confirm that his answer to the Senate a moment ago boils down to saying that the Minister in question was simply talking codswallop?

—I have not spoken to Mr Howe about this, but I recall that last week we got three different versions of a particular policy from assorted people on the Opposition front bench. I am more interested in which policies are delivered, and this Government has delivered on policy over the past seven years.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In view of the signs of a softening of South Africa's position towards its black majority, as evidenced by the release from prison on 15 October of seven African National Congress leaders after serving lengthy sentences, has any approach been made by the Federal Government, or is one contemplated, to try to obtain the release of ANC leader Nelson Mandela?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Government made clear at the time of the release of the press statement by the then Acting Foreign Minister, Mr Duffy, the Australian Government absolutely and unequivocally welcomes the unconditional release from prison on 15 October of eight democratic political leaders, although our positive response to those releases is, of course, constrained by the knowledge that, as Senator Jones has intimated, Nelson Mandela and hundreds of other South Africans remain in prison because of politically inspired activities. Nelson Mandela himself, in welcoming the releases, is reported to have said that many other people serving long term sentences should be released before him, and that his release was, as he put it, not on the agenda now.

ANSWER.PARA: Notwithstanding that, we will continue our longstanding efforts to urge the South African authorities to release Nelson Mandela and other political prisoners unconditionally, to repeal current repressive laws, to allow free political expression and organisation, and to negotiate now with authentic black leaders on a non-racist democratic political system based on equality and dignity for all South Africans. The Ambassador has made this view known to South African Ministers, including the Minister for Justice, in a number of discussions over the past year and in recent months and will continue to do so.

Of course, Australia's position in this respect is very clearly on the record, most recently as a result of our efforts in Kuala Lumpur at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. The Australian Government considers it vital that Mandela, when he is released, is able to join other genuinely representative black leaders at the negotiating table with South African authorities and is not released into a political vacuum. It is encouraging in this respect that the release of the eight was unconditional and not subject to restriction orders. It was also encouraging that the celebrations and meetings which have accompanied that release were orderly and posed no danger to the safety of the community at large. In that respect, I pay particular tribute to the moderation shown on both sides of the very large meeting which has taken place in the last day or so in South Africa and which was reported extensively in this morning's press. Finally, it would be a significant and most welcome sign of the new South African Government's open door approach and willingness to negotiate were it to release Mr Mandela immediately.

But that issue will be resolved ultimately only when the pilots sign contracts with the airlines and resume work, as they should have done some six or eight weeks ago.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen an article in today's Australian which claims that the Government, through cutbacks to the budget of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), is reducing its efforts in environmental research? Does the Minister agree with these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am provoked to comment on that article, which I have seen. It refers to claims by the Opposition spokesman on science that `two senior CSIRO environmental scientists have been sacked because of federal government funding cuts'. That claim is fatuous and utterly without foundation. It is one of a series of claims being made on a variety of issues by the Opposition spokesman on science and technology. If I had the time I would spend it writing letters to the newspapers pointing out the outrageous and absurd nature of claims made by Mr McGauran. He seems to be totally unaware of the structural and financial plan announced by the CSIRO board earlier this year in conjunction with the senior officers of CSIRO, the division chiefs. That plan, which was implemented at the behest of the CSIRO board itself, called for reductions in staff numbers over the next three years due to an urgent need to reduce the Organisation's very high current ratio of salary to operating costs so as to provide more flexibility and higher levels of support in areas of high priority.

ANSWER.PARA: In line with the board's plan, which requires CSIRO divisions to rationalise their activities and target research into areas of high priority, both the Division of Soils and the Division of Entomology reviewed their research projects in order to meet this objective. I do not want to go into the details of the nature of those reviews and the decision about what the priorities were. But a high priority of environmental research in the Division of Soils is combating soil erosion and salinity. This is in line with the Government's view and the Prime Minister's statement on the environment, and the views of the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Conservation Foundation, which have jointly identified this as a matter in need of urgent attention. I would have thought that Mr McGauran might have supported that. About $500,000 a year will now be put into work on these aspects of soil degradation over the next three years. As I say, that claim by Mr McGauran is one of a set of silly claims made by him as shadow Minister for science in recent weeks.

I draw the Senate's attention to one or two issues which he is not talking about in public, those matters which relate to cuts in funding for research announced in the Opposition's Economic Action Plan. Amongst the things which the Opposition proposes in that plan are, firstly, to withdraw Commonwealth support for the national industry extension service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this a speech?
—No, it is whatever you like. I will make a speech if Senator MacGibbon wants.
—Well, why won't you tell us why you cut the funds to CSIRO in the first place?

—The Opposition proposes-it may be an unpalatable thought to Senator MacGibbon, if he has any thoughts at all-to withdraw Commonwealth support for the national industry extension service. It proposes to put an overall budget ceiling on the grants for the industry research and development scheme. Since such a ceiling already exists, it is a strange suggestion from the Opposition. One must assume that this would mean a reduction in financial support for the scheme. It proposes to abolish the forestry industry research fund-something which might be of interest to Senator Stone and Senator Boswell as representatives of the National Party of Australia in this place. It proposes to terminate funding for research and development in the coal industry under the national energy research and development program. It proposes to withdraw Commonwealth assistance to the rural community-based research program. All those issues are things which Mr McGauran, as Opposition spokesman on these issues, has not seen fit to advocate in the Australian community. Instead, he puts out this rubbish about the alleged effects of CSIRO funding cuts on the reorganisation of CSIRO.

Is the NHMRC requiring further studies from registrants of chlordane, heptachlor, aldrin and dieldrin? Specifically, is it requiring inhalation toxicity data? Finally, is there any interim report and, if so, will the Minister make it available?
—I am not able to answer Senator Coulter's question in the detailed way in which he seeks an answer. So I will put it on the Notice Paper and get back to him in due course.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware that Dr John Hewson has made a number of criticisms of economic forecasts contained in this year's Budget? Is he aware that Dr Hewson has made criticisms of Budget figuring in most years since 1983? Has the Minister compared Dr Hewson's record as an economic forecaster with that of the Commonwealth Treasury? Finally, will the Minister be recommending that the Government alter its forecasts to conform with Dr Hewson's?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Hewson has questioned the accuracy of economic forecasts in the past, especially those economic forecasts which have a direct and significant impact on Budget outlays. I have not had time to look at all the comments that Dr Hewson has made which are on the public record, but in view of Mr Peacock's recent confident statements about future unemployment levels in Australia under different scenarios, I have checked Dr Hewson's record on forecasting levels of unemployment. For example, in the Business Review Weekly of 26 September 1986, Dr Hewson roundly condemned the 1986 Budget estimate of unemployment during the 1986-87 financial year. Indeed, he devoted most of the article to discussing that topic. He concluded:

ANSWER.PARA: This year's budget calls for an estimated average number of unemployment benefit recipients of 595,000. The likely outcome is closer to 650,000 or 700,000, even on the most optimistic assumptions.

I repeat: he said that even on the most optimistic assumptions the range would be 650,000 to 700,000. The actual figure came in at 574,000, which was 100,000 less than the median figure of the range that Dr Hewson suggested and, indeed, 20,000 below the Treasury estimate. Earlier in that same article Dr Hewson noted that the 1982 Budget forecast of the number of people in receipt of the unemployment benefit during that year had been `wildly in error'. He claimed that that was part of a conspiracy by senior Treasury officials against the then Prime Minister. Dr Hewson wrote:
Undoubtedly, part of the error in those forecasts related to the fact that some of the `powers that were' in Treasury at the time . . .

It should be remembered that this article was written in 1986. He spoke in the past tense in regard to Treasury officials of the day-and one Treasury official in particular, I suspect. Dr Hewson continued:

. . . the `powers that were' in Treasury at the time were not prepared to admit the possibility of a substantial rise in unemployment to a `disturbed' Malcolm Fraser, for fear that he might seek to blow out the deficit announced in the 1982-83 budget.

He did that, anyway. But as far as I am aware Senator Stone has never denied that very serious allegation which is very clearly levelled at him because of the reference to `powers that were' in Treasury. —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, is about apartheid and South Africa. Has the Minister noted a downtrend in the price of gold in the last few years? What in the view of the Australian Government are the implications of this for the already troubled South African economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The price of gold internationally has fallen from an average price of $US608 in 1980 to $US437 in 1988. It is currently around $US360. Industry analysts are divided about whether the downward drift in the dollar price has yet come to an end. In the past decade South Africa's share of world gold supplies has fallen from 52 per cent to 27.5 per cent. As a percentage of the Western world's production, South Africa's decline has also been sharp, decreasing from just over 70 per cent in 1980 to a forecast of just under 40 per cent in 1989. That decline has been absolute as well as relative. The peak production was reached in 1970, when South Africa produced 1,000 tonnes. Since then it has, with small fluctuations, been in continuous decline to an estimated 616 tonnes in 1988. South African gold output has been declining in recent years because of high running costs and deep lodes. South African mines used to have the world's lowest production costs, but they have lost their competitive edge as new mines have opened in North America and Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The combined effects of that decline in production and in the price of gold are having a particularly damaging effect on the South African goldmining industry and its prospects. They are also having a very significant effect on the South African economy, in which gold plays a very central role. Gold remains the country's most important export. In 1988 gold accounted for 38.4 per cent of all South African export earnings. It accounts for almost one-eighth of gross domestic product and 10 per cent of all government revenues. The industry last year accounted for 7 per cent of gross fixed domestic investment. It employed 536,000 workers and is estimated to provide approximately 10 per cent of the state budget via indirect taxes. It is the basic industry which has created the Witwatersrand industrial complex and provided prosperity for many white South Africans-not too many blacks.

The South African economy could not survive in its present form without foreign exchange earnings from gold to sustain its balance of payments position. As income from gold declines and continues to decline, obviously the South African Government comes under increasingly intense pressure to reform in order to regain access to international markets generally and in particular to financial capital flow resources now being denied to it.

Periodically there is against that background speculation-or in some quarters agitation-about the introduction of sanctions against South African gold exports. However, until such time as a reliable process is developed to distinguish South African gold from the gold produced in other sources-and such technological capacity for drawing a metallurgical distinction of that kind does not presently exist-the potential of sanctions specifically directed against this most important export of the country must remain limited. The export of Krugerrands has already been curtailed by international actions, including Australia's decision in August 1985 to prohibit the import of Krugerrands and all other coins minted in South Africa. That is, of course, a sanction which we will maintain.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

ANSWER.PARA: The remainder of Senator Vallentine's question really related more to her general philosophical view of the world rather than to specifics. ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security explain the meaning of the dependency ratio and its implications for the Government's social policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not surprising that we get that sort of response from the other side, because the question asked by Senator Devlin relates to a very important social indicator. I suggest to Senator Hill and Senator Puplick-who may still be here after the next election-that it may be important for them to understand what the indicator is all about. In essence, the dependency ratio is the number of people dependent on pension or benefit for every 100 people in the work force. It is illustrative to look at the history of this ratio over the past few years to see how it has moved and the implications involved in that. At the end of 1975 the dependency ratio stood at 30.9 dependent people for every 100 workers in the work force. Over seven years later it stood at 43.7 for those 100 workers, and six years later, in June 1989, it went down to 33.6 per 100 workers. In essence, there has been a cutback of 25 per cent over the last six years and that compares quite favourably with the increase by some 43 per cent in the period from the end of 1975 to March 1983. That period reflects very much the policies of the same three people who are at the forefront of economic development in the Opposition at the moment: Hewson, Stone and, in latter days, John Howard. As I said, there has been a substantial increase, and this is a very important social indicator because it shows the degree of dependency on benefits and pensions.

ANSWER.PARA: These figures and their history have some quite clear implications. First of all, the period of seven years or so up to 1983 was a reflection of the policies of the time. Not only did we have economic policies that were conducive to higher unemployment, but we also had the same degree of slackness in approach to checks and fraud control that is now part of the Opposition's political action plan. Senator Chaney was the responsible Minister then. He was one of the group of five or six who developed the current social welfare policy direction. He removed checks on unemployment beneficiaries then. He removed checks that would have ensured personal lodgment of unemployment benefit forms. He also removed the requirement to register with the Commonwealth Employment Service. That is the same sort of policy which we have been confronted with but which we are told will now be much more stringent in its application.

It is illustrative to look at our history in recent years to see the implications of what this Government has done. We have tightened the welfare system quite substantially in a number of areas. For a start, we have delivered a tighter welfare system in relation to the front door, the entry into the system. Now people cannot get into the system without adequately proving their identity and eligibility. We have also tightened review processes in a number of diverse ways. We have review processes to detect wrong payments and to encourage compliance. Those processes include the mandatory personal fortnightly lodgment of unemployment benefit continuation forms, highly effective mobile review and selective review teams--

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a disgraceful use of Question Time.

—They include effective use of computers to select people for review and they include implementation of uniform Commonwealth prosecutions policy. I say to Senator Lewis that the only conclusion one can make about the last six years is that our reforms have in fact prompted an active social security system which is also tighter and more efficient. Senator Lewis was there at the time. He was part of the group of six that came up with the economic policy. How can he interject when, after we have achieved these major goals in the area, the Opposition spokesman comes up with what he calls policies for tightness and fraud control which, he says, would wipe out fraud in the sector?

ANSWER.PARA: When one looks at the sorts of claims that are coming from the Opposition, one gets a very stark portrayal of the shallowness and ineptitude of its position. On the weekend Mr Connolly came up with a figure of $500m. We have three figures on the basis of the same set of statistics from one spokesman. Not only that: Mr Peacock in the plan that Senator Lewis put his signature to said that--

TALK.START.PARA: —This is disgraceful.
—He said that he would save $30m. Of course, we have figures again this weekend from the shadow Treasurer, who earlier this year said that social welfare cuts would not cut back on fraud at all.
—He has been going for 7 1/2 minutes making a statement.

—Senator Lewis may not want to listen to this, but it is probably important for him to get to understand it now before those opposite go out onto the hustings and make further fools of themselves. Those opposite are great pretenders in this area. Our policy and performance in the area of social security--

Senator TATE The second reading speeches read as follows:
CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (ANTI-DUMPING) BILL 1989

This Bill, together with the Companion Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1989, proposes a series of amendments to the Commonwealth's anti-dumping legislation, contained in three Acts: the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975; the Anti-Dumping Act 1988; and part XVB of the Customs Act 1901. The amendments contained in this Bill give effect to two substantive proposals, and some other technical amendments.

The first substantive proposal effects the restructuring of the provisions dealing with anti-dumping matters into discrete taxing and non-taxing Acts. This has involved the repeal of a substantial number of provisions of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act, effected by the companion Bill, and the transfer of those provisions to part XVB of the Customs Act, effected by this Bill. A detailed analysis of the repeals and transfers, including a concordance of the provisions affected, is contained in the explanatory memoranda to both Bills.

The purpose of this exercise has been to avoid possible difficulties arising out of the High Court's decision in Air Caledonie International v. the Commonwealth. That decision relates to section 55 of the Constitution and the treatment of taxing and non-taxing provisions, and it has raised doubts about the proper placement of some of the provisions in the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975. The Government has decided to put those provisions beyond doubt by transferring them to the Customs Act.

I turn now to the second substantive proposal in this Bill which is aimed at implementing the Government's recent decision, announced on 10 September 1989, on the inclusion of a profit margin when the normal value of goods is being `constructed'. Dumping occurs when the price at which goods are exported to Australia-the export price-is less than the normal value of the goods in the country of export. This normal value is usually just the price of the goods in the domestic market of the country of export.

Sometimes, however, that price is unavailable-for example, because the goods are produced only for export, and are not sold on the home market; they are unusable; or when the exporting country has a centrally planned economy. The normal value must then be obtained in some other way. One such way is to add up the costs of making and selling the goods within the country of export and, in appropriate cases, to include a margin of profit. Such a normal value is said to be constructed.

One possible reason why the domestic price might be unusable would be that the overseas company had been selling the goods in its domestic market at a loss, for an extended period of time and in substantial quantities. Under subsection 5 (9) of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act, which is to be subsection 369TAC (12) of the Customs Act, such sales would be considered not to be in the ordinary course of trade, and their price therefore would not be usable as a normal value.

In 1986, the Government asked Professor F. H. Gruen of the Australian National University to review aspects of anti-dumping policy. Professor Gruen's subsequent report made many recommendations for change, most of which were accepted by the Government. In his report Professor Gruen noted, and deplored, an increasing propensity to use constructed normal values. He noted, too, that such values could be substantially above the actual domestic price.

He therefore suggested that the number of constructed normal values should be reduced to the absolute minimum and that this be achieved by repealing subsection 5 (9) of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. He went on to say that, if this approach were not adopted, more realistic normal values could be obtained by not including a profit in constructed prices.

In the event, the Government decided to retain subsection 5 (9) of the anti-dumping Act, but to tighten some aspects of its use. In particular, it decided that, unless there were strong reasons to the contrary, a zero profit should be assumed when subsection 5 (9) was being used.

However, this intention could not be achieved by amending subsection 5 (9) itself. The operation of that subsection might make it necessary to construct a normal value, but the method of construction-including the matter of a profit margin-was specified in three other subsections of section 5 of the then Act, any one of which might be used in a given case. The amending legislation passed by this Parliament last year therefore included changes to each of these three other provisions. In each case, the amendment was to the effect that a profit would only be included in circumstances specified in regulations to the Act. The same legislative package created a new Anti-Dumping Authority, which came into existence on 1 September 1988.

Shortly thereafter the Government referred to the new Authority the question of what regulations might be made to prescribe the circumstances when a profit component should be included in a normal value construction. The Authority held a public inquiry into this and some other questions referred to it at the same time, received and considered many submissions, and reported in March 1989.

In its report, the Authority distinguished sharply between the construction of a normal value because subsection 5 (9) had been invoked, and the construction of a normal value for any other reason. Subsection 5 (9) comes into play only when prices, in the domestic market of the exporting country, have been unprofitable for an extended period. Under the Authority's rationale, had the sales not been at a loss their price would probably have been accepted as a normal value and construction of a value would have been unnecessary. The constructed value should therefore take account of all costs, so that sales at that price would not be at a loss; but there was no reason to include any profit.

The Authority went on to argue that, when a normal value was being constructed for any other reason, a profit should indeed be included. The margin of profit allowed would vary from case to case, and could sometimes even be zero. Like other components of a constructed normal value, it would always be so chosen as to obtain the best estimate possible of a fair price within the domestic market of the country of export.

The Authority reasoned that the inclusion of a profit, which might be zero, in such cases would improve consistency. A company, for example, might produce two kinds of goods, export both to Australia but sell only one on its domestic market. For the latter goods, the domestic price-which would usually include some profit-could be used as the normal value. For the other goods, a normal value would have to be constructed; and for consistency it, too, should usually include that same level of profit.

The Authority considered, and rejected, the argument that profits should never be included in constructed normal values, to keep these values as low as possible. If the construction process tended to lead to overestimated normal values, it reasoned, the solution should be found in revising the process rather than in compensating for the error by an arbitrary exclusion of profit from all constructed values. The Authority also considered arguments that the level, if any, of profit to be included should be decided by referring to the conditions facing the relevant Australian industry, such as its need for protection against dumped imports. This argument, too, it rejected. The Authority said in its report that it could not `see how the current condition of, say, the Australian lampshade industry can conceivably be relevant to the normal value of (say) Egyptian lampshades sold on the Egyptian domestic market'. I must say that I agree. The Government has considered carefully these conclusions by the Authority, and agrees with them.

In its report, the Authority went on to recommend regulations which might be made under the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act to achieve these effects. After consideration, the Government has come to the view that these same objectives can best be implemented by amendments to what was section 5 of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. Under other changes proposed today, that section will become section 269tac of the Customs Act. Its wording, as proposed to be amended, allows a profit, which may be zero, to be included in a constructed normal value except where the reason for con-struction is that subsection 269tac (12) -the equivalent of the old subsection 5 (9)-has come into operation.
Financial Impact Statement
The proposed amendments in this Bill have no direct financial implications. I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the accompanying explanatory memorandum.
CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

This is the companion Bill to the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill 1989. This Bill effects the repeal of a substantial number of provisions of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act, as well as making other necessary amendments consequent upon the transfer of these provisions to Part xvb of the Customs Act 1901. The rationale behind the restructuring of the Commonwealth's anti-dumping legislation is explained in detail in my second reading speech on the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: PASTURE SEED LEVY BILL 1989

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the imposition of a levy on pasture seed produced in Australia, as requested by the Grains Council of Australia as the body representing pasture seed growers. The funds raised by the levy will be used to finance a pasture seed research scheme. The Government will provide funding to match industry levies as part of its broad program of encouraging increased rural productivity through research. Before speaking on the Bill itself, I should place this current research initiative in the context of the research arrangements in place and the changes which are planned following the release in May 1989 of the joint ministerial statement on research in the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio.

The Government has placed a great deal of emphasis on the administration and funding of rural research in Australia with a view to further improving the contribution of the rural sector to the national economy. The first major step in this process was the passage of the Rural Industries Research Act in 1985. The research councils established under that Act and portfolio research and development (R&D) corporations established under separate Commonwealth legislation administer commercially oriented research programs with a total budget of $141m in the current year.

Consistent with the policy reflected in the Rural Industries Research Act, the Government has encouraged rural industries to increase their contribution to existing schemes up to at least 0.5 per cent of gross value of domestic product. It has demonstrated its commitment to match industry funding dollar for dollar to the 0.5 per cent level and it has also encouraged new schemes such as the proposed pasture seed scheme which is the subject of the Bill before the House. Rural research is the biggest single budget item within the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio, with 1989-90 expenditure expected to increase by $80m.

As reflected in the May 1989 research statement, the Government has continued to explore avenues to increase the benefits to the individual industries and to the community in general of the significant level of research expenditure. R&D corporations have been identified as having advantages over the research councils and other administrative structures for funding R&D in respect of administrative and funding efficiency and effectiveness. The corporations will become the model for revised R&D funding arrangements. The Government will be holding discussions with industries on the specific research arrangements to apply and will be presenting a Bill for an Act to replace the Rural Industries Research Act and other arrangements to implement those changes. In addition, a Primary Industries and Energy Research Council will be established to promote a high policy forum and networking facility for R&D, to further develop consultation on R&D policies and to improve the linkages between portfolio programs and the efforts of outside research organisations.

The proposed pasture seed research scheme will be administered initially by the existing Australian Special Rural Research Council. The funds to be raised by the levy would be insufficient to justify the establishment and maintenance of an industry specific research council. As a body catering for research into a number of emerging industries, incorporation within the Special Research Council will ensure that administration costs are in reasonable balance with total expenditure on research. Under the proposals for future R&D arrangements being developed by the Government, the Special Research Council will be replaced by the proposed Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation, and it is envisaged that, in the first instance, the proposed pasture seed research scheme will become a responsibility of this Corporation.

Turning now to the Bill before the Senate, the pasture seed industry makes a contribution of fundamental importance to Australia's livestock and pastoral enterprises through the provision of bulk quantities of pasture seed of the required quality and varieties for pasture production. The development in recent years of significant export markets for Australian pasture seed has added a further dimension to the industry's importance as a contributor to regional economies.

Pasture seed production occurs throughout Australia but predominantly in the temperate areas of South Australia, Victoria, Western Australia and New South Wales. Annual gross value of production of pasture seed has been estimated at $57m, while export earnings have been around $10m per annum.

Pasture seed research to date has been funded mainly by State government and livestock industry research schemes. To support the industry's continuing role in domestic agriculture and encourage the further development of export opportunities, Australian pasture seed growers have identified the need for an expanded research program into production, storage, transport and marketing of pasture seed. The establishment of a joint Commonwealth-industry scheme will broaden the industry's research funding base and assist in enabling the industry to achieve its full potential.

In view of the widespread and significant production of pasture seed in Australia and the administrative problems that would likely occur in effectively levying all production, the pasture seed industry agreed that only certified seed of certain pasture species and cultivars be levied. The levy will apply initially to specified certified seed of clovers, medics and lucerne produced in Australia. Provision is made for certified seed of other pasture seed species and cultivars to be added to the scheme.

As marked variations in value can occur both within and between species of pasture seed, the legislation provides for different operative rates of levy for different leviable cultivars. On commencement of the scheme, certified seed of the medic, clover and lucerne cultivars set out in a schedule to the Act will attract a levy of $7.50, $10.00 and $12.50 per tonne respectively. The legislation provides for new operative rates to be added and for existing rates to be varied by instrument. The maximum rate for any one cultivar is established by the legislation at $50 per tonne. The legislation requires that the growers organisation recommend any variations to the levy rates and the pasture seed to be covered by the scheme.

The levy is payable by the grower and will be collected on the Commonwealth's behalf by State or Territory government departments responsible for seed certification. State government Ministers in all States in which leviable seed is produced have agreed to these arrangements and a formal agreement between the Commonwealth and each participating State covering the collection arrangements will be put in place. Inclusion in the scheme of further pasture seeds which are also grown in States other than those currently participating in the scheme would be dependent on agreement being reached by all States in which the additional seeds are grown.

Amounts equal to the levy will be paid into a separate account established for the purpose of the Australian Special Rural Research Fund. The Commonwealth's matching contribution will be up to a maximum level equal to 0.5 per cent of the average gross value of leviable pasture seed production. It is expected that in the first year of operation the levy will raise $106,000. The Australian Special Rural Research Council will therefore have scope for an annual pasture seed research program of the order of $200,000.

The commencement date of this legislation will be on royal assent. It is intended that the levy be imposed on pasture seed produced in the 1989-90 harvest and the research program commence in 1990-91. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
PASTURE SEED LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1989

The purpose of the Bill is to provide the machinery necessary for collecting the levy imposed by the Pasture Seed Levy Bill 1989. This Bill should be read as one with the Pasture Seed Levy Bill 1989 and is to come into operation on the same day that the levy Bill becomes operative.

This Bill gives authority to the Commonwealth and States making arrangements for collection of the levy, outlines penalties for non-payment and provides appropriate powers of enforcement. There are no financial implications other than those covered in the second reading speech for the Pasture Seed Levy Bill 1989. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1989-90[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1989-90APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1989-90]

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1989 and cognate Bills. This legislation finally gives the Senate the opportunity to debate the 1989-90 Budget of the Hawke Labor Government; something that Labor, of course, is not anxious to do. That was clear yesterday when an unprecedented number of Labor senators decided to speak in the debate, but not about the appropriations as such. It was typical that, in the immediate aftermath of the Budget, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his speech at the National Press Club devoted only two pages of his eight-page speech to the Budget and the rest to an attack on the Opposition. If Government senators have a lead, the lead is from the Treasurer. It does not necessarily have to make sense, but that is the ploy.

SPEECH.PARA: It is typical of a rather ideas-bankrupt Government that it sees its only hope of re-election as attacking the alternative government, and it is equally a sign of the times that its attacks have been falling increasingly flat. For a week the Treasurer was reduced to saying that the coalition Economic Action Plan is no good because Opposition members are dreadful people. He had no facts or figures, and still has no facts or figures, after he has spent a week misusing the Department of Finance for party political purposes, trying to get it to do his dirty political work for him. It is less an Exocet missile than a custard pie that he is able to throw, and it is a great tragedy that he has wasted taxpayers' money on using the Department of Finance to try to blow something out of the water that he is clearly unable to do.

The Treasurer has had to admit that there are no errors in our taxation estimates. His criticism of coalition spending projections are based on nothing more than his own questionable suppositions that long term unemployed people are totally unemployable and that older Australians all want to give up work and will not take up the deferred pension plan. It is tragic that the Treasurer has said, in his own words, that the long term unemployed will be unemployed forever and that he dictates that all older Australians must give up work. Those two things are a reflection of where the Government is at. The Government does not understand the realities of today's climate, of what people really want. The long term unemployed are not necessarily unemployed forever; they need to be given the incentive and encouragement to get back to work.

The Treasurer can no longer get his own arithmetic right, when his attack on the Economic Action Plan makes contradictory estimates as to whether the number of Australians on special benefits will increase by 340 per cent or 600 per cent. Which is it-340 per cent or 600 per cent? I contend that it is neither, but neither figure has been based on anything more than self-interested guesswork. The Treasurer in subsequent weeks, after misusing the taxpayers' money in the Department of Finance, has still not been able to give anything more than the figures that were originally based on that guesswork.

It is of no comfort whatsoever to Australians to be told that the Hawke Labor Government is signalling `Steady as she goes' through this Budget, against its own predictions of 7 1/2 per cent inflation, which is already shown to be wrong, and a current account deficit of $18 1/2 billion for 1989-90. The only direction in which Australia is moving under this Government is steadily down the gurgler. From private conversations that have been about-and I will not name names-I think many Government members realise that, and it is quite evident to the people of Australia that the country is on very shaky ground. It was only on 16 July that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) stated that the public did not recognise the gravity of the economic situation. The Minister for Finance was saying in crystal clear terms that he believed the situation was grim.

Thanks to the Labor Government, from March 1983 net Australian foreign debt has risen from $23 billion to $108 billion; the repayments on which absorb 30 per cent of the value of Australian exports, with the servicing of external liabilities taking more than $1 billion per month in foreign exchange earnings. Australian foreign debt per capita, $7,000, just happens to be 10 times that of the Philippines and three times that of Argentina, the country that at the beginning of the century was said to be our equal in economic potential and is now held up as a dreadful warning-but we are worse. The Government cannot pretend that capital goods imports are largely responsible for the deficit when in 1988-89 these have risen by $2 billion against an overall current account deficit deterioration of $5 1/2 billion. It would take only a 10 per cent decline in Australia's terms of trade to add another $6 billion to the current account deficit.

The two broad strategic paths out of that morass are complementary. We can as a nation tighten our belts-and heaven only knows how many times people have been asked to do that-or we can increase productivity. This Budget and the entire Keating policy thrust concentrate upon the former option, while leaving the second and more constructive option in the too hard basket because it involves hard decisions that are absolutely unacceptable to the political masters of this Government, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU).

It is a fact that, ever since monetary policy was eased in 1986 in order to get interest rates down to win the 1987 election, this Labor Government has relied excessively upon interest rates to reduce demand. Rates of 17 per cent plus for home buying families, if they are lucky enough to have loans with the four big banks, and of 21 per cent for small business, are the consequences of this policy. Only yesterday we saw that people had to be earning $64,000 to buy an average home in Sydney, worth about $117,000, and then would be forced to make mortgage repayments of $1,600 per month. How on earth can people afford to do it? But this is a direct consequence of this Labor Government's policy.

This Labor Government may boast of its large Budget surplus but let us not forget one thing: this is obtained not by real reductions of Federal Government expenditure but through increasing taxation revenue and further reducing payments to the States. That is what this Government is all about: the tightening of other people's belts rather than its own. The Treasurer, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Finance all go on ad nauseam about the necessity for people to tighten their belts. Why do they not practise what they preach? In real terms there has been a further reduction of 4 per cent in payments to the States in 1989-90 while real overall spending marginally increases and will rise by 1.3 per cent in 1990-91. On one hand, they are chopping out distribution of the funds to the States but, on the other hand, they are continuing to increase the tax take.

As I heard my colleague Senator Bjelke-Petersen say last night, it must still be remembered that this is the biggest taxing, biggest spending government in Australia's history. There is no getting away from that. This is not to say that the Federal coalition does not fully recognise that big spending State governments are a major cause of the national debt problem. One only has to look at the most classic example-my own State of Western Australia-where former Premier Brian Burke and current Premier Peter Dowding have been having a field day. At whose expense? At the taxpayers' expense.

Yet Senator Robert Ray said here the other day that the Government would always look after the needy. Who are the needy? In Labor terms, the needy are the Abeleses, the Harrises, the Kodaks, the Murdochs, the Packers, the Connells and the Bonds. How enlightening it was to see a report on the Four Corners program last night showing where the money is coming from for the funding of Labor Party election campaigns. It is coming from those wealthy people. What for? Why would they be donating in such huge amounts? It is not just through love, I can assure you.

When in government we will reduce general purpose payments to the States by $300m while expecting a saving of $600m in State Budgets through the adoption of contracting-out policies. This figure is a small proportion-11 per cent-of our total program of expenditure reduction. The approach of the Hawke Labor Government has been entirely different, forcing the States to take more than their fair share of cuts without regard to the fact that higher State charges only fuel the consumer price index and add to business costs.

Make no mistake: this Budget surplus is being funded by increased taxation, moving to a record taxation share of gross domestic product (GDP) of 25 per cent. The major responsibility rests with Labor's old friend, bracket creep. I am now talking about bracket creep in its literal sense and not in the way the Treasurer is often referred to. That will push up income tax receipts by 10 per cent. It has added $13.5 billion to revenue since 1982. This cost will be met by middle income earners, the people that this Government purports to care about. By July 1990 those people will lose half the July tax cuts to bracket creep as they await a contrived reduction in interest rates in time for an election. Yesterday Minister Howe talked about further tax cuts and big handouts, making a big fellow of himself. Maybe the truth came out today when the Minister for Finance tipped a bucket on Minister Howe and said that the Government simply could not afford them. Who is right and who is wrong? Talk about contradictions!

Since the last coalition Budget of 1982 total Federal government receipts have risen from $44 billion to $97 billion, a rise of 119 per cent. If anyone needs clarification as to whether this Government is a big taxing government, it is almost contained in that one statistic on its own. Tax on individuals is up by 123 per cent; taxation of companies has risen by 138 per cent; other taxes, such as the fringe benefits tax and that on superannuation funds, which are Labor initiatives, have risen by 133 per cent. Indirect taxes are up by 124 per cent, including a rise in sales tax of 200 per cent.

I want to dwell on the figures for indirect taxes and sales tax. This Government pooh-poohs any suggestion made by commentators-or anyone else, for that matter-about the possibility of a consumption tax. This Government already has a de facto consumption tax. The indirect taxes and the sales taxes constitute a consumption tax by sleight of hand, by another name. The Government says, `We would not have a consumption tax'. Not likely! They already have it in place. This litany of taxation impositions, courtesy of the Australian Taxpayers Association, shows that private business meets much of the cost of this enormous spending Government. We can almost admire the sleight of hand displayed by the Treasurer, who ruthlessly attacks the profitability of the private sector without formally raising the rate of company tax. The effect, however, will be no different.

There is absolutely no accident about the fact that the highest projected increases in tax receipts are from those taxes that impact most directly upon business. Company tax will be up by 10.7 per cent; the fringe benefits tax will be up by 13.2 per cent; the prescribed payments system will be up by 26 per cent; and the category including capital gains tax will be up by 20 per cent. Changes to the method of company tax collection so that 85 per cent must be remitted within a fortnight at the end of the financial year might seem to the Treasurer a very good and simple mechanism for inflating his heralded Budget surplus. What it will really mean is a reduction in profitability flowing through to smaller business and wage earners and cash flow problems that could result in the bankruptcies of major enterprises.

The Treasurer does not seem to care less. He comes up with smart ideas, and that is about where it ends. It has already been well stated by the Victorian Chairman of the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia, Mr Barr, that the construction industry is particularly vulnerable to the loss of cash flow that this Budget measure creates. I can only agree with Mr Robert Oser of Price Waterhouse that the new system is a thinly disguised tax surcharge based on the unfair comparison that, while the individual wage earner collects income evenly, company cash flows are uneven. Business costs will also rise through the requirements of remitting pay as you earn (PAYE) receipts on a fortnightly basis, prompting the announcement from Coles-Myer that this will add $67m to its annual borrowing. Once again, does the Treasurer mind that impost on the private sector? No, not at all.

For too long the Hawke Labor Government has posed as a friend of business. I suppose it is a friend of business-big, big business. It is a friend of the airlines. It is a friend to Kodak. It is a friend to a lot of people who might dip into their pockets at an appropriate time. Certainly Labor governments have the capacity to develop cosy relationships with individual corporations. I believe it is now time to judge the Treasurer on the effect that his policies are having on the private sector, that is, the only engine of growth that Australians have. In the majority of cases, of course, that involves small business, not huge corporations.

It is not in the interests of business for a government to preside over an inflation level that, since 1983, has been 1 1/2 times that of Britain, twice that of the United States of America, five times that of Germany and eight times that of Japan. It is not in the interests of business and the community to have a government that eagerly presides over a centralised wage fixing system that acts to put a floor under inflation. The coalition does give credit to the Government where it is due on the rare occasion that it can. It supports the measure of financial deregulation that has been achieved since 1983. However, reform is just one area. It does not entitle the Labor Government to acclaim that it favours and assists free enterprise.

The private sector can receive lasting and effective assistance from financial deregulation only if this is accompanied by other reforms so that business decisions can be made in full accordance with market realities, leading to the rise in productivity that is essential to overcome the debt crisis. The Government talks much about productivity but does nothing. I think probably the most classic and current example is that of the pilots dispute, which we and Australia know is still in existence but which the Government says is not in existence, if one can understand that.

Deregulation of financial markets is one thing, but it is in fact admitted by this Government's own Business Regulation Review Unit that 17,400 government employees are involved in the regulation of business, with a further 960 regulators working full time in agencies formerly outside government departments. The cost of business regulation multiplies in its effect to $47 billion or 19 per cent of GDP which is a substantial amount. In 1987, 184 Acts were passed affecting the business portfolios and 340 statutory rules imposed. While 40 of these took regulations into new ground, only seven repealed existing regulations. This has come from a Treasurer who, when he was first elected, said that he was going to make taxation simpler and easier to understand. No-one can now understand it. The accounting firms are struggling. They are capable of understanding it, but the problem is that the Treasurer keeps changing the rules; and not just changing them but adding to the problems.

The greatest failure of this Government is its refusal to institute truly basic reform of our regulated transport system and labour market because, once again, its political masters, the Australian Council of Trade Unions have dictated that the accord for which we are told ad nauseam we must be grateful must stay in place. Just what does this Budget do to free the labour market, to improve competitiveness and to institute reform? It does absolutely nothing; not a thing. This is the overwhelming criticism that the coalition makes of this Budget, and is entit- led to make, because we are putting forward some positive answers in our Economic Action Plan which is making an impact in the electorate. That is why the Treasurer and the Prime Minister fantasise about the mistakes that they think should be there but which they cannot find, even though they have wasted taxpayers' money by asking the Department of Finance to find and unearth those mistakes.

The cornerstone of our reform program is an industrial relations policy that looks to an enterprise based wages system, promising a 25 per cent increase in productivity, which is going backwards by 0.2 per cent each year under the accord. That is the record of this Government. Productivity and everything else is just going backwards. We are going to break out of our productivity malaise by giving employers and employees the right to negotiate wages and conditions, to give immediate sanctions and flexibility to the current system, to remove the dead hand of compulsory unionism and bring the wage earner into partnership through incentive schemes and wage increases based on productivity.

Wage increases will not be based on something that is in fairyland-that because someone in Sydney might get a pay rise, that automatically means that someone in Adelaide must get a pay rise. It will be based on productivity. Complementary to this, of course, we will free those resources tied up inefficiently within the public sector through privatisation, so that taxpayers and consumers both benefit from a higher standard of service.

It is interesting to note that the coalition for many years has talked about the possibility of privatisation, yet it was this Government that tried to terrify the electorate year after year, at both State and Federal elections, that privatisation was bad. At least the Government in recent years has seen the merit of our argument. We will extend privatisation to a point where the people of Australia will benefit more and more. We will attack business regulation through regulatory impact statements provided by Ministers, systematic review of existing regulations, rigorous impact assessments of new regulations and deregulation agendas for each department.

Coastal shipping-another classic example of where this Government has failed to make any impact at all-will be exposed progressively to competition, with manning levels brought to the levels of comparable Western nations. There must be genuine, permanent change on the waterfront based on individual enterprise so that export industries are no longer held to ransom, with a 20 per cent productivity improvement leading eventually to a $1 billion increase in GDP.

With telecommunications costing the average business more than $30 per week per employee, we shall deregulate a range of Telecom Australia services that will cut business costs. It is not good enough for this Government to tolerate a monopoly situation where the Industries Assistance Commission has measured Telecom as being 20 per cent less efficient than the Canadian system, which caters for similar population distribution. Look at the profits Telecom has made. Look at the way the Government is protecting that industry. Yet it says that it is going to provide greater opportunities for cost cutting in this Budget. It is simply not so.

The coalition will also be radically different from this tired, worn out Labor Government in its determination to maintain necessary Budget surpluses through expenditure restraint rather than higher taxation. That is the difference. We will not be taking more and more tax from the taxpayer just to provide a little goody before an election; we will actually be tightening our own belts and not those of the taxpayers. Expenditure savings of $2.7 billion reflect the necessary balance of compassion and realism, aiming at a leaner and better targeted service delivery, and giving back incentive to work that has been eroded through a social security system that relies on unemployment benefit for permanent income support and forces us out of the work force at 65. As the shadow Treasurer, Dr John Hewson, has said repeatedly, this Government has created a situation where people can leave school, go on to unemployment benefit and only come off it in time to go on to the age pension. That attitude must be turned around.

A small but significant part of our savings, totalling $9.5 billion, will be made at the expense of the partisan misuse of public money that Labor is unable to resist-the postage rort of taxpayer funded direct mail advertising, Government feel-good type propaganda advertising campaigns and the National Media Liaison Service, which supplies the Australian Labor Party media tactics at taxpayer expense. Our taxation commitments will focus on the area of greatest need-the beleaguered Australian family-with $2 billion of rebates for spouses, children and child-care as the traditional family adapts to a pattern of increased work force participation.

Small business will no longer be condemned to stay small. Small business operators can look forward to reward for effort instead of being sent out of business in the way in which this Government is quite cleverly doing. When the destructive capital gains tax is replaced by a tax focusing on speculative gains, people will be prepared to invest their money, and many times to the benefit of others. For example, in the housing sector, if people are not prepared to invest money to buy homes, how can other people-those who cannot afford under the policies of this Labor Government to buy their own home-rent them? How can they afford $1,600 mortgage repayments per month on an average home?

In the months ahead, aiming for a soft landing for a May election, if not sooner, we will be encouraged to forget the candid remarks by Senator Button on 14 July, when he described the Keating J-curve theory of economic recovery as `forgotten and unlamented' and that in reducing real incomes it was `a painful approach that impacts unequally on the community'. At least Senator Button on that occasion may have got it right. Unfortunately, the National Media Liaison Service, which controls the media of this country, is not prepared to be honest enough with the public to say that the Treasurer has got it wrong and is getting it more wrong by the week. Month in and month out we see the figures which show that we are going further and further down the Argentinean road. We have to turn it around now or pay the price forever more. Clearly, Senator Button has been unable to convince the Treasurer of the self-evident truth of Senator Button's remarks. Australia has a Budget designed to win an election and nothing else. That design provides, of course, for the manipulation of interest rates while continuing to ignore our massive and continuing structural problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on the Appropriation Bills this afternoon, I would like to make some remarks with respect to the coalition's Economic Action Plan. I will make those remarks in two respects. Firstly, I will state why I believe that that action plan is the appropriate course of action for this nation. It provides the right direction, the one we should be taking. Secondly, I will refer to the Government's response or, rather, lack thereof, to this plan. As Senator Knowles pointed out in her speech, no one could suggest that the Australian economy is healthy. That is a bad thing in a variety of ways. We have an unproductive economy at the moment.
