SPEECH.PARA: It is just not possible to imagine that the schoolchildren who are present in the gallery are taught that our economy is better than, for example, Japan's. The reason that they are not taught that is that their teachers do not lie to them. We do not have an economy that is better than Japan's. The trouble is that we do not have one that is better than West Germany's, either. I could refer to the extensive list of Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries which have a better and stronger economy than ours. That means they have better opportunities to offer schoolchildren when they leave school to seek jobs, and better opportunities for business people. Sure, private enterprise wants to make money. This seems to upset Government members. They forget, of course, that when private enterprise makes money it generates jobs for people who can then be independent of the welfare system, earning a salary and making decisions about their lives. That is a good thing.

The coalition's economic policy does two things on which I want to concentrate. Firstly, it outlines comprehensively $2.7 billion worth of expenditure cuts. We say that it is about time that the Federal Government realised that while everybody is told that they must tighten their belts, the Federal Government has not been doing that. It is about time that Canberra cut its cloth just as every Australian family and small business have had to do. The coalition has done that. We have put our cards on the table and said, `These are the cuts we have to make, these are the areas that they will come from'. This allows people to assess whether we have made the right decision.

That is not what the Government has done. We do not hear much from it about what it will do, unless the August Budget is about to be handed down, or one of its now regular mini-Budgets, to try to fix the mess that it made the year before, is handed down. It does not tell us in advance what will happen, for example, in the May mini-Budget next year, which will undoubtedly be presented if we do not have an election before then. The Government is not putting its cards on the table, but we have done so. I think it is a good thing that the Opposition is prepared to put its cards on the table, to stand by the decisions that it must make in order to have better government. It gives the media, the people in the press gallery, the opportunity to go to the Government and say, `What about it? These people have now said where they will make their expenditure cuts'. We have done that so that there can be a full and proper debate on the course of action that we will take when we win government.

There will be no surprises when we win government at the next election. People will not be able to say, `We didn't know you were going to do that'. There will be no surprises at all. We have laid on the table, fair and square, where the cuts will be made so that everybody knows, and so that there is plenty of opportunity to debate that matter beforehand. As I say, I think it is a good thing that a Commonwealth government is prepared to cut its cloth in the way in which it demands everybody else should cut their cloth-in the way in which families, small business and the States do.

The second aspect of the coalition's Economic Action Plan on which I want to concentrate is the family tax package. It represents a very substantial change in direction from what this Government is doing. Finally, after many years, there is an acknowledgment of the changing pattern of women in the work force-something that this Government has not sufficiently acknowledged. We have done that in two ways. We have indicated that we will institute a new program of child tax rebates, because families with children necessarily have more costs. If families have more children, there will be more Australians, and that is obviously a good thing for us. Families have extra costs and we should acknowledge those costs and make a contribution to them. A family with one child does not have anything like the costs of a family with four, five or six children. So under our program a family will receive more money if it has more children. I think that is a good thing.

The other aspect of our family tax package is a program of child-care tax rebates, varying between $10 and $20 per child. It is in this area that we separate ourselves from the path that the Government has chosen to take. Basically, the Government says that people whose children are attending some sort of child-care facility that receives Commonwealth funding can have some help from the Commonwealth, but if they do not choose that course of action for their children, if they choose to put their kids into a private child care facility, the Commonwealth says, `Forget it, you don't need any help'. That is rubbish. Our commitment is to families with children. We say that they need more help than families without children. We say that the more children they have, the more help they need.

We acknowledge the changing pattern of women's involvement in the work force. There are now far more two-income families than there were many years ago. There has been a progressive increase in the number of married women entering the work force and, therefore, a progressive increase in the number of two-income families. That necessarily means that there is a demand for more child care. Not everybody will choose to use government based child-care facilities. We think it is unfair that people get help only if they choose government funded child care. We think that two-income families should get some assistance for child-care costs, irrespective of what choice they make. The Liberal Party is about, among other things, individuals making choices for themselves. Big brother in Canberra should not decide where the next community child-care centre will be built and how much people will pay. We say that parents should decide where they want their kids to be looked after. It is a very good thing that the child-care tax rebates will be available irrespective of whether children are placed in a government or private child care centre.

That has produced a quite dramatic response from the Government. It knows that although it has made some gain in the past decade with regard to the women's vote, it is not losing it. It has been losing it for the last couple of elections, but it will record a massive loss in the women's vote at the next election. The reason is that the Government is still saying to women with children, `If you go to a government centre you can have some help'. It is saying to all the other women with children, who need child-care assistance in order to continue their career, `You can get lost'. On the other hand the coalition is saying, `We acknowledge that you may now be choosing to work; we acknowledge that some women are working now because they have to as a result of the parlous state of the economy and the fall in the standard of living'. What we are saying is fundamentally different from what the Government is saying. We are saying, `You choose where you want your kids looked after and we will give you some assistance irrespective of your choice'. So the women who have had the door slammed in their face by this Government, the women who have been left out in the cold, will vote for the Liberal and National parties. There will be a huge reduction in the support that women have given to the Australian Labor Party at the next election. I think that is a good thing. That means that we will be in government very soon.

The second aspect I want to address in relation to the coalition's Economic Action Plan is the Government's response to it, or lack thereof. You may remember, Mr Acting Deputy President, that in the weeks leading up to the announcement of this plan there was a big brouhaha in the press gallery and through the media generally as to how Mr Keating, the Treasurer, was like a cobra waiting to strike. We were to put up an action plan and Mr Keating would demolish it. That afternoon a major flaw would be found in our policy, Keating would be the victor and we would look pretty stupid. We released our action plan and we waited for the cobra to strike. As Senator Stone pointed out in this chamber recently, the cobra became a carpet snake and could not find a major flaw in our policy. The Government could not find where to cut $2.7 billion off its programs and it certainly was not prepared to make the commitment to Australian families with children that the coalition has been prepared to make. So, for about 24 or 48 hours we had a deathly silence from the Labor Party. Panic was setting in.

But the Government has now changed tack and it has realised that it has to try to demolish this action plan one way or the other: it has chosen the other. It has chosen to criticise the plan by saying that it is nothing other than what the Liberal Party of Australia Federal President, John Elliott, has dictated. We have heard Senator Walsh in this chamber, we have read in the media, and we have no doubt heard over the airwaves and in the television comments that we are simply doing what John Elliott wants: we want to make the rich richer. That really is a case of the pot calling the kettle black.

I was listening to Senator Knowles's speech earlier this afternoon when she was referring to the very big mates that this Government has and what it has done in relation to, say, media broadcasting for its big mates. As to the compensation being paid to the airlines, we all know that Sir Peter Abeles is a very close friend of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). His company is able to weather the storm of an industrial dispute because we, the taxpayers, are funding it. That does not happen to every business in Australia. I think it is the first time it has happened. But because Sir Peter Abeles and the Prime Minister are big mates, the Government is happy to pay that money to allow airlines to weather the storm a bit longer. I say to the Government that it should not judge everyone by its own standards. Just because the Government is running a government for rich mates by rich mates, there is no reason to assume that everybody else will do that. As I say, what the Government has done in the last term of office about media legislation and compensation to the airlines is a good example of that.

The specific aspect of our Economic Action Plan that the Government has chosen to concentrate on and to portray as being a neat trick to give more money to John Elliott is our promise to remove the Labor Government's capital gains tax and to replace that with a speculative gains tax. All honourable senators in this chamber will have heard on various occasions what one might call a bucket job being done on this particular policy. The inference is that because it is perceived that Elliott will have a gain that he otherwise would not have, as a consequence of this policy being introduced, that is the reason it has been done. As I say, just because Labor thinks that way, that is no reason to think that is the way we think. What the Government has done is totally turn its mind away from the very positive aspects of our policy.

There is no question that we will get rid of Labor's capital gains tax. It is a complicated tax. It works against investment in production and encourages over-investment in the family home because the family home is exempt. It denies incentive and, in that sense, reduces reward for effort. People who have operated small business know that. They put their life blood into a business, they build it up to try to get some capital gain out of it and take that capital gain and build further to make a bigger and better business. Labor would have it that that is a bad thing. I say that is a good thing because when business is taking more opportunities it is generally creating more jobs. Sure, opportunities sometimes will be taken and lost; and in those circumstances, jobs will not be created. But at the same time people who have made the investment will lose their home and any other capital that they have put at risk. Sure, they did this in order to get some profit for themselves but at the same time they were creating jobs.

The complaint is made by honourable senators on the other side that it is totally inappropriate that capital gain made at any time-whether it is three, four or five years-become tax free. Frequently the Government uses as an example that pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayers cannot do that. They work for five years and do not get any reduction in the tax that they pay. The reason is that small business people are putting capital at risk. They probably have a second mortgage on their house. They put everything they have on the line and risk it for that business. The people they employ as PAYE employees do not do that. Why should they get the same reward? The PAYE employee is not creating jobs. That is what we need in this country: jobs created. We have to build an economic environment where the entrepreneurs will get out there and do their thing, where there will be more entrepreneurial activity; therefore, more productivity; therefore, hopefully, more profit. As business grows, employment grows and with that individual wealth grows, dependency on welfare reduces and individuals can make more choices for themselves.

Let me repeat some remarks in relation to our decision to remove Labor's capital gains tax. The coalition's policy will provide major assistance to small businesses by recognising that capital gains on their investment often provide the superannuation for men and women who run Australia's small business enterprises. Our policy encourages long term investment by removing a tax penalty. Our policy removes the bias to invest in domestic residences which at the moment are free of capital gains tax but rather to investment in plant and equipment which can now be subject to a capital gains tax. Our policy, naturally, will direct investment funds into more productive activity. Our policy also removes a major impediment to the formation of a dynamic venture capital market for risk investment services.
In conclusion, I wish to refer to three people and their comments in relation to these policies. Firstly, the well known independent tax expert, Mr Eric Risstrom, has indicated that:
. . . even the Treasurer Paul Keating must concede that the law is too complex to continue as now.

So we have the former president-I think he was-of the Australian Taxpayers Association indicating that the current tax is just too complicated. If we turn our minds back to the tax summit that was held in the old Parliament House, one of the key points made by the Treasurer was that a tax system needs to be simple. Clearly, the capital gains section of this Government's tax system is not a simple one. It is just far too complicated. As Government members take their daily opportunities to rubbish our policy, let me remind them that, in the 1983 election that saw many honourable senators on the other side come into Parliament, Mr Hawke said that there would be no new capital gains tax. In September 1985 the promise was broken. On that basis we need not put too much credibility on what the Government says about capital gains taxes or speculative gains taxes.

Mr Keating says that the loss in Government tax revenue as a result of removing the capital gains tax is estimated at $450m a year, and that is based on an estimate made by Mr Keating as recently as August 1989. The remark has been made that we cannot afford to make the change we are making. I draw the attention of the Senate to the $2.7 billion worth of cuts that have been outlined.

In summary, I think the coalition's Economic Action Plan is a good one, because it does two very important things. It cuts the Commonwealth's cloth by $2.7 billion, and that is a good thing. It offers massive assistance to families and acknowledges the changing pattern of women's involvement in the work force by giving child-care tax rebates to those women, and that is a good thing. The final thing I want to say is that, the sooner that plan is implemented via the coalition being elected to government so that we can get the Australian economy back on track, the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1989-90 and cognate Bills has centred on the contest between the Government's economic policy and the Opposition's Economic Action Plan. That is a good thing. It is some time since we have had an opportunity to debate two such plans. We have often taken the Opposition to task about its failure to produce a plan, and finally it has done so. It is entitled Economic Action Plan-The Liberal-National Parties' Economic and Tax Policy, October 1989. The people of Australia can now properly compare the policies put forward by the Government with those put forward by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout this debate honourable senators from both sides of the chamber have contested mightily the question of which is the best plan-and quite properly so. I shall follow the lead of other speakers in the debate and refer first to the Economic Action Plan. Obviously, I cannot go through the document page by page, paragraph by paragraph, but various matters deserve specific comment.

On page 7 there is a reference to `The Looming Crisis'. On page 8 there is a chart about external debt. According to the chart, Australia's external debt is such as to bring this country in third after Brazil and Mexico. The source of this data is the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. The proposition is that Australia is up there with Brazil and Mexico, that things are grim, and that therefore it follows that the Opposition's Economic Action Plan will succeed-or I suppose a better way of putting it is that it ought to succeed.

However, what is not in this document, on this page and on many others, is an analysis of where that external debt has been created and what it means. I understand that the Economic Action Plan put forward by the Liberals and the Nationals was costed by a group called Access Economics Pty Ltd. That concern purports to have expertise in economics, such that the Opposition has embraced Access Economics Pty Ltd as worthy costers of its Economic Action Plan.

In considering Australia's external debt, about which the Opposition takes the Government to task, what better authority could we go to to see what that means than Access Economics Pty Ltd, the very body that has put pins and stays under the Liberal and National parties' Economic Action Plan? I refer to the Access Economics Investment Monitor, published in October 1989, the very month in which the Economic Action Plan of the Liberal and National parties was published. The Access Economics Investment Monitor is described as follows:

A unique listing by sector and State of 500 investment projects worth over $5m each, under construction, committed, or under consideration, in mining, manufacturing, tourism and public sector investment related to foreign exchange earnings.

It ought to be emphasised that this is investment related to foreign exchange earnings, the sort of investment which down the years will bring foreign exchange earnings to Australia. We are talking about not only investments which will produce income in Australia but investments which will bring Australia's foreign exchange earnings up. That is what we are talking about. This is what Access Economics Pty Ltd says about the projects which will earn us foreign exchange income in the future:
Projects listed have a total value of over $90 billion.
As a proportion of total investment tourism represents 34 per cent, manufacturing 30.5 per cent, the public sector 21 per cent and mining 14.5 per cent.
Access Economics says further:
We have included projects in mining, manufacturing and tourism as major sectors with the potential to earn foreign exchange.

It is a pretty happy picture. When one looks at the next chart provided, `Table 1-Investment by Industry', one sees that there are vast investments in the manufacturing, mining and tourism sectors. In the manufacturing sector, for example, there is investment in food, textiles, wood, paper and printing, chemicals, non-metallic minerals, basic metals, transport, other machinery and miscellaneous areas-and so it goes on. At page 4 of the Access Economics Investment Monitor the following statement is made:
This picture-
the picture presented by Access Economics-
is in sharp contrast with the resources boom when projects were heavily concentrated in mining and basic metal products. For example, the June 1982 official survey of investment projects-
during the time of the previous Fraser Government-

had $28 billion out of $32 billion (or 87 per cent) of investment at the committed or final feasibility stage in mining and basic metals. Even within these areas there was a heavy concentration in iron ore, coal, alumina and aluminium.

Access Economics contrasts that situation with the situation that has arisen under the present Government, where there has been a wide diversity of and a great increase in investment, that investment having been in projects which will ultimately earn income for this country from overseas. The point must be made that, no matter who is in government in the 1990s, Australia will benefit considerably from the efforts that have been made under this Government in getting Australia to a situation where overseas earnings will come from a wide variety of industries, providing a basis for Australia to go on to greater and greater things economically.

It is not good enough to say simply that overseas debt does not embrace the issue. The issue is what sorts of things have been done with the money that Australia has been borrowing, what sorts of things will that bring about in years to come, and what will be the result of that investment? The Economic Action Plan does not undertake a proper analysis of where the money is going. It should because the very people who played a major part in producing the Economic Action Plan at the same time were producing the Investment Monitor which analysed very clearly where that money was going. It is interesting to note that our overseas debt is mainly a private sector debt. The private sector is using that money to fuel the economic boom that will come in the 1990s in the way I have already described. Page 25 of the Economic Action Plan states:
The Australian economy is about to enter its most difficult period since the Second World War.

That is the sort of statement we expect in a document that is the basis for a coming campaign in a Federal election. As we would expect it says that doomsday will come under this Government and the parousia is coming from the Opposition. As we expected, that is a bit of a pup as is the next statement which reads:
The economic mismanagement of the Hawke/Keating Government has left Australia with a legacy of debt, the servicing of which has already mortgaged the future of the next generation of Australians.
Again, that is another statement which is to be expected in the political context. The next statement in the document is a bit naughty because of the way it is put. It reads:
Much of the money has not gone into productive investment and exports which would serve that debt; it has been frittered away to try to artificially prop up the living standards.
That is a very neat way of getting around the embarrassing fact that most of the money, as I have said, has gone into investments. The document says:
Much of the money has not gone into productive investment . . .

The positive statement is that much of the money has gone into productive investment which will service that debt. The Economic Action Plan is a political document in so far as it tries to embrace an embarrassing situation. As Access Economics must have advised, the embarrassing situation is that this debt is debt created for the building up of economic infrastructure of this country. The Opposition realises this. How can it get over that embarrassment? It attempts to get over it in a negative way by saying, `True enough. Much of the money has gone into productive investment. We cannot contradict that fact, but we will not put it into this document. We will say that much of the money has gone into productive investment'. However, the Opposition does not bother to say how much has been frittered away in trying to artificially prop up living standards. That is very interesting. If that money has gone into artificially propping up the living standards, why does the Opposition-and I will come to this point-go on wanting to prop up the living standards of people in Australia who are better able to afford the economic rigours than are others? The Opposition cannot have it both ways. If it does not want the living standards of Australians built up, why does it not say so?

My next point has been commented upon again and again but I think it is worth a further comment. It refers to the unemployment relief plan which is set out on page 35 of the document. It says that if the Opposition ever came into government it would slash unemployment benefits by $1,500m. On page 36 it says that it would increase special benefits by $835m. That is a saving of something like $600m to $700m. The surprising thing about this is that the unemployed are picked out as the people to suffer the lashes of economic restraint. Of course it would not touch the age pensioner group. It would allow them to keep their property. They would be allowed to own their property, have their children work their land and get the old age pension as well. Nobody could cavil with that if there were enough money to go around. The Opposition purports in this document to save the money by taking on the unemployed. It is interesting that the weaker section of the community should be attacked.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have done it before.

—They have but, on the other hand, there has been a long history in the conservative parties of the shire tories-I think that is the best description of them-having a concern for the weakest in the community. I refer to a famous quotation by the Earl of Beaconsfield when, as Benjamin Disraeli, he wrote Sybil.
—He was not a member of the Liberal Party.
—Senator Messner purports to inherit all the great principles of the conservative parties of the past. In Sybil the Earl of Beaconsfield wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: I was told that the Privileged and the People formed Two Nations. Two nations, between whom there is no intercourse and no sympathy; who are as ignorant of each other's habits, thoughts, and feelings as if they were dwellers in different zones, or inhabitants of different planets; who are informed by a different breeding, are fed by different food, are ordered by different manners, and are not governed by the same laws . . .

That is the approach the honourable senator takes. I have an extract from the data of the Department of Social Security quarterly survey of August 1989 which says that there are 159,600 long term unemployment benefit recipients who will now be cut off without compunction and who have 88,300 children who will be similarly cut off in order to benefit people who, as I have said, are already well off. In July 1974, Mr Robert Ellicott, a member of the then Opposition, took to task the proposals of the Whitlam Government which was giving money to those better off sections of the community at the expense, as Mr Ellicott saw it, of the poor. He said:
Who will come first-the poor or the affluent? Have we the courage now in this country to express in a material way the humanity which we have so often expressed through our lips?
He went on to say:
What does the average Australian who is not poor require in times of economic stability by way of social welfare of his Government?
He went on to criticise that approach.

Fifteen years later the members of Mr Ellicott's party forget or ignore-whichever is the right word-the warning he gave then. He then warned against exactly what they now embrace. Mr Ellicott quoted from President Roosevelt who, in 1937, said:
The test of our progress is not whether we add more to the abundance of those who have much-it is whether we provide enough for those who have too little.

The present Pope, John Paul II, said that the quality of a society and a civilisation is measured by the respect shown to the weakest of its members. If the Opposition comes into power, what will happen to the people about whom Benjamin Disraeli, Robert Ellicott and the Pope are concerned? On 1 November 1977 in a speech on the individual in need, Senator Peter Baume, one of the most outstanding senators on the Opposition benches, quoted Alfred Deakin who, in 1885, gave an address entitled, `What is Liberalism?'. He said:

The reconstructive element in Liberalism must in future come to the front. In political economy, having induced politicians to discard the old program `The Devil take the Hindmost' Liberalism would now indicate a new teaching with regard to the poorest in the community, that all should have what was their due. By fixing a minimum rate of wages and wise factory legislation, wealth would be prevented from taking unfair advantage of the needy. The latter would be saved from leading wretched and imperfect lives . . .

That was said almost 100 years ago, but with the Economic Action Plan it will all be thrown out. The Liberal and National parties, if they got into power, would immediately take away unemployment benefits from almost 160,000 people with over 88,000 dependent children. They would do so not on the basis of any test or investigation, but simply on the basis of an arbitrary declaration that anyone who has been on unemployment benefits for nine months or more is somehow an evil blot on the community. It is all right if such people have been on unemployment benefits for eight months, or even eight months and three weeks, but if they have been on that benefit for eight months and four or five weeks they turn from being reasonable people whom society will support to being evil people who can be thrown in the trash can, have the lid put on them and then cast into the outer darkness.

TALK.START.PARA: —Condemned.

—That is so. If the people who have been on unemployment benefit for nine months are then 64 1/2 years old, they will be thrown away from society for six months, as if they were refuse; they become blots on society. As soon as they reach 65, they become heroes, old age pensioners, people of repute who are outstanding examples of what we want in Australia. It does not matter so much who we are or what we are, but how old we happen to be and for how long we are out of work.

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody could approve of people ripping off the system, whether it be a workers' compensation system, a Commonwealth system or a pension system. I can understand people saying that there ought to be tests, investigations or inquiries to see whether people should receive a pension, but I cannot understand their making an arbitrary determination to put people in the trash can, slam the lid on them and cart them off to the rubbish tip, only to bring them back shortly because they have become old age pensioners who are then put in beautiful surroundings. The Opposition's idea is to take us from heaven to hell and back again, not on the basis of any sort of test other than that of time periods. It is considered that someone who is 64 years 11 months and three weeks old is fit for nothing but the refuse heap of society. If that person lives another month, he is suddenly brought back and given a pension. His children are allowed to work his land and earn money and he becomes a hero. It is a logic that requires some sort of imagination to follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —It takes a bigger imagination to dream it up, Barney.

—As we all know, Senator MacGibbon is a reasonable man. The Opposition proposes restriction of receipt of unemployment benefits to nine months. The only thing to stop people getting a pension under the coalition scheme is whether they have been on unemployment benefits for eight months and three weeks or nine months and one week-a tremendous transformation takes place in that fortnight! It is chameleon-like. People go from being grubs to being butterflies. Depending on how long they live, they might be put back as grubs or be brought back as butterflies when they turn 65. That is the scheme. In any event, whether from grub to butterfly, butterfly to grub, refuse heap to parousia, heaven to hell, the Opposition believes that the process must be good because it will save $600m. I suppose we have to pray that there are more grubs than butterflies so that we can save more!
—We on this side of the chamber would not pray for that.

—Certainly not! I turn now to the subject of education and the Opposition's proposal that an annual tuition charge of $1,200 will be payable by tertiary students. My view, for whatever it is worth, is that in hard economic times there ought to be some sort of contribution by students, but that it would be fairer to follow the course taken by the Government and let students make the payments when they have finished their studies and have started to earn. I will tell the chamber that they do not pay back their parents once they start to earn, as I have found from bitter experience.
—Name them!
—I will not name them. All I get from them are parking tickets to pay.
—They will look after you in your old age, though.
—I do not worry about their looking after me in my old age if I go out of office, but about whether they will look after me if I become unemployed in the meantime, because that is the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: I now speak on the topic of invalid pensions. An invalid pensioner is totally and permanently incapacitated, but under the coalition scheme, even if an invalid pensioner is permanently incapacitated, he will be required to undergo an annual check. Somebody might explain to me how somebody who is permanently incapacitated can recover within a year. A paraplegic with terrible spinal cord injuries who cannot move his feet or his legs will have to be wheeled in every 12 months to be examined by a doctor. When asked what is wrong with him, he may not be able to answer because he may have brain damage. That process is devoted towards the end of saving $150m. Who will pay for the paraplegic, quadriplegic and brain-damaged invalid pensioner to be wheeled in every 12 months to be examined by a doctor? Somebody might answer that question for me.
Finally, I talk about privatisation. On page 15 of the Economic Action Plan it is stated:
The Coalition has already decided on a number of bodies to be privatised when we are elected:

They include Australian Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd, the airport terminals, the Australian Industry Development Corporation, Overseas Telecommunications Commission, Aussat, Medibank Private, the Pipeline Authority, and the Commonwealth Bank.

The document said that this would save, or introduce, millions of dollars for the good of the Australian people. The reality is that that will probably only add to our external debt. Where is the private sector going to get the money from to buy all of those things when it has already caused the present debt crisis because of its borrowings?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very silly remark.
—The honourable senator says that that is a very silly remark, but that remark is taken up by Tandberg, who is a brilliant cartoonist, in the Age newspaper.
—He is not well known for his economic expertise.

—That cartoon illustrates the situation very well. Because Telecom Australia has announced a $973m profit, one of the characters in a cartoon in the Age is saying to the other, `Telecom should be sold off to private enterprise!'. The other character says, `Private enterprise would borrow heavily overseas'. The first character then says, `Then it could be run at a loss to avoid embarrassing profits'. This document makes many statements and suggestions, but it is just not worked out. Senator Messner says that Tandberg is no great economist, but apparently there is no great economist on whom one could call to tell us how this Economic Action Plan is going to work. The only document to support it all is the group--
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many fine speeches have been made by senators on the Liberal and National Party benches in support of the Economic Action Plan recently announced by the Liberal and National parties. Quite often in this place, we sit and listen to Senator Cooney with rapt attention as he tells us in an entertaining manner about the faults of plans such as ours. However, we could not have done so today. We had to sit in absolute horror as we listened to his total misrepresentation and misunderstanding of the policies of the Liberal and National parties. He had to quote from Benjamin Disraeli to throw back at us the issues that have been raised in our action plan. That really does beggar description. Firstly, let me pick up on one point that Senator Cooney made. He was trying, as he always does, in such a plausible barrister fashion, to tell us--
—They call him Rumpole down in Melbourne.

—Yes, he would suit that role very well indeed. Senator Cooney was trying to tell us that the Liberal and National parties stand for privatising Telecom Australia, which is absolutely untrue. We do not intend to privatise Telecom. We plan to deregulate those sections of Telecom that should be and are subject to competition from the private sector. Those things are totally divorced from the basic telephone network. The objective, the plan and the policy of the Liberal and National parties is to maintain that basic network in the hands of the public sector. Please, Senator Cooney, do not continue to misrepresent our position.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me pick up on one other point that Senator Cooney mentioned. He kept emphasising how all of those people who are unemployed for nine months will be suddenly thrown into the trash can and the lid will be bolted down tight. Senator Cooney failed to mention that our policy will provide that those individuals who are in that unfortunate situation and who are unable to find employment will be endowed with support for training and new jobs. Alternatively, they will be able to apply for special benefits under the present criteria. There is nothing unfair about that. It means simply a change from one category of benefit to another. I can see Senator Walsh nodding in approval of that kind of approach, because he knows that our proposal would lead to a far more effective saving. As a result, the taxpayer would save money.

I return now to Telecom. As part of the Budget debate I would like to draw attention to the report of Telecom which was released yesterday. We were all interested to learn that Telecom's profit for the last financial year was just short of $1,000m, which is a very considerable profit compared with the $776m of the previous year. During the past four years, Telecom's profit has increased from $464.6m to this year's figure of $973m.

The point to which I wish to draw the attention of the Senate is that, during that period, the rate of return on Telecom's capital assets has increased from approximately 10.8 per cent to something like 13.8 per cent. In terms of profit, that is a creditable performance. However, that means that, from every dollar that is invested in Telecom's operations, we-the Government or the taxpayer-make 13.8c, which is not a huge return by today's high interest rate standards. For instance, people know that they can invest their money with a building society or a friendly society and obtain an interest rate of 17.5 per cent. Yet Telecom is investing its money at about 13.8 per cent, which is somewhat less than 17.5 per cent. Telecom's performance is still a long way short of what might be expected in money markets generally.

The point from the financial statements to which I really wish to draw the Senate's attention is that, in each of the past two years, there has been a special deduction from profits-$187m last year-for special depreciation. That constitutes an unusual picture because it is not classified as ordinary depreciation on plant and equipment but rather is described as being `as a result of Service Life Changes'. I suppose that means that there has been a reassessment of equipment. Indeed, because of today's fast-changing technology, one can understand that the cost of replacement of equipment is rising. Therefore, one would expect higher depreciation claims in respect of equipment replacement. That has another connotation. It seems that, if that figure were added to the profit of $973m which has been disclosed, Telecom's profit, as adjusted, would be of the order of $1,160m, which is very much more than what has been disclosed in the accounts.

Today in the Senate, Senator Alston asked the relevant Minister about Telecom's community service obligations. Senator Alston asked when information about that was going to be provided, there being a report that is in the course of examination by the Minister. However, the Minister could not provide an answer about that even though he has had that report for six weeks. That report is totally relevant to the issue of Telecom's profits. If we are to rely on Telecom's argument that it needs to make profits of such a substantial order, something over $1 billion, in order to fund its obligations to the community-for example, such people as farmers in isolated areas who need special subsidy for their telephone services-we need to know as soon as possible what those costs are. Today Senator Alston made the point that it could be as low as $100m. Therefore, if it is only that amount, we have to ask: Why is it necessary for Telecom to earn a profit like $1,160m? The numbers do not stack up. Therefore, the arguments are not entirely straightforward. I should like to hear from the Government as soon as possible about the result of its inquiries into this matter. Quite clearly, the reason for Telecom's high profits being argued in that fashion may not be strictly correct. Certainly, we in the Liberal and National parties would like to hear the answers to that.

I will now refer to one or two other relevant points about Telecom. We note that, during this next financial year, there will be a revaluation of all the assets; that is, the land and the buildings, of Telecom. It is anticipated that that could add some $2.5 billion to the asset base. That will change considerably the return on assets of the profit, which means that, in order to maintain the same level of return as it had in the last financial year, Telecom will be looking for even a far greater profit, perhaps to the extent of as much as a third of what it presently is, in the next financial year. That could mean a profit in the years ahead of something like $1.5 billion. These figures are very rough and are arrived at only on the basis of inadequate information provided by the financial statements for the year. But it does indicate that Telecom will have to either make greater efficiencies or obtain far greater throughput of its traffic in order to generate that kind of profit level in the future.

It is interesting that some of the areas of Telecom's activities are growing very quickly. One wonders why the Government does not let Telecom off the leash and allow it to become totally deregulated so that it can get into new areas. Take, for instance, the cellular mobile telephone services that are now operating. I see that, in the past financial year, the number of services multiplied by 300 per cent. The figure went from 31,000 to 94,000 in one year. That is an enormous rate of growth which suggests an enormous opportunity for future profit growth for Telecom. Obviously, as it is such a strong growth area, there ought to be deregulation of the cellular network immediately and the introduction of a second cellular network, perhaps in private hands, to compete with Telecom and to provide even cheaper services than are being provided by present operators for mobile telephones. Obviously, this is the way of the future and it is time that the Government let Telecom off the leash so that other enterprises can compete with it on a fully competitive basis in the new areas of technological development. In turn, that would generate greater taxes for the revenue, improve telecommunications and efficiency and productivity in the economy generally.

While I am on the subject of infrastructure, I point out that one of the areas of which I am sure many honourable senators have become aware in recent times is the problem relating to the condition of roads in this country. If they had driven recently between Canberra and Adelaide the number of times that I have, they would have noted the standard of the Sturt Highway. Very clearly, there is a need to examine such infrastructure questions.

This leads to the whole question of how we in this country should go about the funding of infrastructure development in the years ahead. It is certainly coming up very quickly now as a major priority for government action at State and Federal levels. We are seeing in the United Kingdom the continuing privatisation of major infrastructure developments such as water supply and electricity. Those things are leading to more effective and efficient operations, but at the same time, although there are some extra costs to consumers involved, they are improving and will continue to improve and update their facilities so as to provide better and cheaper operating facilities in the future.

We have to take a new approach to infrastructure development in this country. It is certainly something that needs to be developed in conjunction with the various States. We have had the recent example of the problems of the sewerage in Sydney. Those problems are a classic example of the lack of expenditure on infrastructure development. Consequently, they will need to be attacked by State and Federal governments in the years ahead. Any problem can be solved in engineering terms, so long as we have the money and the commitment to do it. Therefore, that will be one of the great challenges that we face in the years ahead.

One area in the Budget that is of very great concern to the private sector and about which I am receiving a great number of petitions, as no doubt other senators are, is the change in the system by which company tax will be collected during the next financial year. This will affect companies differently according to the balance dates that they individually have. But on the assumption that companies balance on 30 June each year, under this new government provision, they will be required to pay 85 per cent of their tax due on a notional income calculation no later than 15 days after the end of the financial year. That is an outrageous proposition.

The first question that many accountants will have to address, of course, is how on earth can a person calculate for every company in Australia the exact amount of the taxable income of the company within that short period at the end of the financial year. Within 15 days the profit of a company will have to be determined. That is a practical impossibility.

That will lead to very great pressures, certainly in the accounting fraternity, and obviously will lead to enormous problems unless the Government adopts a very flexible attitude. It will impact mostly, of course, on small businesses. I note that the Government has included very substantial penalties that will apply if companies that have to pay this tax do not get the number right. If they are but more than 10 per cent out from the estimate, they will have to face extra penalties which, under the law, are very substantial. It is unfair and unreasonable. The Government should rethink this proposition, because it will be taking out of the business community almost $900m. That will have to be funded from within the general banking system and consequently it will have a great impact upon the liquidity of small business.

On top of that, although the Government claims that by this measure it will save enormous amounts in public debt interest, it also means that the equivalent amount of money will be put as an extra cost on small businesses at a time when they are seeking to restrain expenditure and to keep the cost of operations to a minimum so as to meet the great competition and the effects of high interest rates. I fear that this ill-thought out measure will cost business greatly and, unless it is modified, it will create enormous employment problems in the small business sector. One would hope that the Government has enough heart to consider the situation and think it through in the months ahead. We have noted that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said that he is prepared to look at the question of small business. We have had no commitment from him at all at this stage, it being now some 2 1/2 months since the Budget was announced, as to whether or not a change is made. I implore him to consider that measure as soon as possible.

It is interesting that in the Estimates Committee, when we sought to ask the departmental officers what consultations had been undertaken with business to find out just what the effects of this measure would be, it was quite clear from the statements from those officers that there was no precise estimate of the impact of this tax on companies; that very little work was done to try to assess how it would affect business and its liquidity. Along with that point, it is quite clear that, broadly, in the context of the recent reduction of the company tax rate from 49 per cent to 39 per cent which the Government announced about 12 months ago, it was expected that this was some kind of trade-off; that because companies now had the benefit of that tax reduction which was supposed to stimulate investment, some of that reduction has to be clawed back by virtue of these new arrangements. That is unreasonable, and quite clearly has not taken account of all the other costs that have been ripped off small business in recent times, such as the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the 3 per cent superannuation increases.

I notice that, since the Budget, the Government has made an announcement about the Commonwealth superannuation scheme for its own employees. The measures that have been announced by the Ministers generally are acceptable and certainly are welcome, but I am concerned that the allowance for public servants to take lump sums rather than pensions will lead to a considerable amount of money being left in the hands of managers. That, along with a number of other measures announced in the Budget for ordinary taxpayers and superannuants, will mean a huge rise in the demand for annuities being provided by various investment agencies in the community. If that occurs, one can imagine a situation where there is simply a shortage of things in which to invest, where it will be difficult for investment managers to be able to generate sufficient returns, sufficient income from their investments, to ensure that the people who have made those investments get an adequate annuity upon retirement.

That may or may not transpire-it would certainly take many years before the full impact could be properly assessed-but it raises the question of whether or not the pressure for investment paper and various investments in the community would lead either to an increase in the cost of annuities that would be charged to superannuants, or to a lower amount in the annuities than people might expect to get as a result of their investment. Overall, that would mean that people would have to put in more money to get the same return as they might have otherwise got or, alternatively, would not get as much upon retirement and, therefore, would not have the security in retirement that they expect. That is a consequence of very great effect and importance, and I hope that the Government will examine it properly in the course of its continuing examination of the superannuation system as it applies to its public servants.

Another superannuation measure announced in the Budget is the new arrangements and tax incentives for people outside the Public Service arrangements to take annuities rather than lump sums. It was predicted by the Treasurer in his statement that $60 billion per year could be going into superannuation by the year 2000. The incentives are such that obviously they will attract enormous amounts of money from those individuals who want to put money away for their own purposes, but where will it come from? We hope that it will come from consumption spending-that is, savings forced on people, from money that they would otherwise fritter away on things such as entertainment.

My worry is that, in the event of that occurring, and annuities becoming more and more popular and attracting more and more money because of the tax incentives, it may well cause people to worry less about owning their own homes. They may well think it wiser, because of the tax advantages, to contribute to superannuation rather than to pay off a mortgage. As a result, we could end up with a situation where fewer and fewer people own their own homes, and the average rate of home ownership-which has always been around 70 per cent-may fall. That would obviously be a bad thing for the Australian community because it would change one of the basic values of all people in this country-that people want to own their own homes.

I believe that there is a danger in the Government's policy of having a tax incentive for superannuation and none for housing, because that kind of proposition could grow over time and people could end up being permanent tenants rather than permanent owners of their own homes. In that situation, we would become like some of the European nations, where there is a heavy emphasis on home tenancy and a reliance on pension income in retirement rather than the model we have had in this country, where people have developed their independence by owning their own houses, by paying off a mortgage during their working lives so that in retirement they have their home plus the capital stock it represents and, on top of that, access to considerable lump sums through superannuation. That is just one of the consequences that may develop, and it is certainly one that would be undesirable if it got out of hand.

A number of issues in the Budget concerning superannuation may have unintended consequences as far as the Government is concerned. The piecemeal approach that the Government has adopted since 1983 has lead to this mishmash or morass of superannuation legislation and regulation, which may well lead us down the wrong track in terms of trying to provide genuine retirement income for Australians. It may take us away from the basic objective of providing Australians with the means to become independent and to provide for themselves in retirement rather than the reverse. That would appear to be one of the most likely outcomes of the Government's policy.

I refer to the cost of housing. A report from the Housing Industry Association which I received recently, and which all senators would have received, on the affordability index for Australian cities, is quite scary. We find that, compared with a year ago, the so-called affordability index-which I think everybody understands these days-has dropped from something like 104.4 to 85.7. The report suggests that in Sydney, for instance, people have to put away 41 per cent of their income to meet mortgage payments. This is outrageous.

TALK.START.PARA: —A real peasant economy.

—Yes, a peasant economy. We are forcing people to live off the smell of an oily rag to meet their repayments. In many cases, no doubt, they have to sell up their houses because they cannot continue with these repayments. This is a direct effect of the Government's high interest rates policy. We have known for the past 15 months that interest rates are destroying not only the building industry generally and the home building industry and the ordinary people trying to pay off mortgages, but also businesses employing people. The interest rate policies that this Government has adopted are wrong. It is time for a change. The Liberal and National parties' Economic Action Plan must be put in place, firstly, to take the pressure off families and to provide them with extra money to stay alive and meet the very heavy imposts that they are suffering under the Government and, secondly, to ensure that the economic policies of the Government get a new direction towards improving the productivity of Australian industry, thereby improving our performance compared with the rest of the world and providing a more secure and prosperous future for all Australians. That is what the Liberal and National parties stand for, what the recently announced Economic Action Plan is all about and why the people of Australia are embracing it so warmly. They know that this Government, the Hawke-Keating Government, has failed Australians and is failing Australians every day. The policies are not working. The circumstances of Australian families are not improving; they are getting worse. Every day that goes by, taxes are getting higher through bracket creep and we are even seeing the imposition of new taxes as I described during my speech earlier. It is time for a change. We look warmly to the day of the next election and immediately thereafter the implementation of a new plan to change Australia's direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating, at considerable distance, the introduction of the Budget, the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1989-90 and cognate Bills, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90 and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1989-90, which constitute the Government's Budget for 1989-90. The Budget was introduced on 15 August, more than two months ago. That is about the normal time span before the Senate debates the Budget but what is more significant this year than in most other years is that this Budget, barely two months old, is already way off course, out of date, irrelevant to the needs of the Australian economy and provides no answers whatsoever to the fundamental economic problems facing Australia, problems which it is no exaggeration to say are of a crisis nature.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, in most respects the Hawke-Keating Budget of 1989 suffered from all these deficiencies right from the very outset. There was no way in which the parameters on which the Budget was based could have been met. That should have been known at the time of the formulation of the Budget and certainly at the time of its introduction. The economic statistics and other events that have occurred in the period of just over two months since the Budget was introduced have confirmed that in no uncertain manner. One has only to look at the situation on the external account where the balance of payments deficit-a cumulative deficit-just for this quarter alone, the September quarter, is $5.8 billion, which is almost $2 billion on average per month, seemingly with no prospect in sight for major change other than one that may be induced by a major slowdown in the Australian economy in the first half of the calendar year 1990 or by the middle of that year.

There is also the risk of an improvement in imports induced by an economic slowdown being offset by problems on the export front for us. For example, some people estimate that wheat export prices are set to dive. Some people predict a fall of nearly 25 per cent in the next year. Other commodity prices are under some pressure as well. The outlook for the balance of payments, so far as the exports side of the account is concerned, is not highly promising by any means. Even if the Government achieves some result in terms of imports by a slowdown in the economy, that by no means guarantees that there will be a net improvement in the balance of payments.

Whether there is a net improvement or not, the fact is that the balance of payments is in an appalling state. It is in an unsustainable position which is, and is increasingly seen to be, of the gravest concern to the future of the living standards of all Australians. The balance of payments accumulating deficit is being accompanied by a continuing massive increase in Australia's foreign debt, a figure which, by the end of June this year, totalled a net $108 billion-that is $108,000m -which compares with $23.4 billion at the time that this Government came to office. In other words, the debt now is approximately five times greater than it was in March 1983 when the Hawke Government was elected. It is not true to say, as the Government has said, that the bulk of our external balance of payments problem is due to capital imports which will suddenly lead to a great burst in productivity increases which will set this country straight and on a more competitive route. Even making a generous allowance for imports of capital equipment in recent times, we go nowhere near meeting the huge and increasing gap in our balance of payments.

The consumer price index again is a figure which was grossly misforecast at the time of the Budget. We have just seen the figure for the September quarter come in at 2.3 per cent, giving an inflation figure of 8.3 per cent for the 12 months to September this year. If one had believed the Treasurer (Mr Keating) when he introduced his 1988 Budget, instead of looking at a figure now of 8.3 per cent we would have been looking at a figure less than half of that. In August 1988 Treasurer Keating predicted that by this time in 1989-90 the figure would be between 3 per cent and 4 per cent. The Treasurer got his inflation forecasts as wrong as he has got his balance of payments figures.

Since the Budget-indeed, this came out at about the time of the Budget, in the week that the Budget was introduced-we have had a very severe criticism of the Government's economic performance. It was the most overtly severe criticism I have ever seen by the Reserve Bank of Australia. If ever one needed an indication of how little the Reserve Bank or the central bank of a country thought about the policies of the government of the day and how concerned it was about those policies, one only needs to read the annual report of the Reserve Bank. That point has been made and debated considerably in this chamber over the period since it came out a couple of months ago.

We do not have to look just at our internal sources of criticism, though. The markets have also judged us accordingly, as have the international credit rating agencies. Both Moody's Investors Service and Standard and Poor's have downgraded our international credit rating, a downgrading which is not just symbolic but which has very significant physical implications. For a start, it means that many of the Australian commercial borrowers overseas have to pay more for their borrowings than would otherwise be the case. It also has a progressive erosion in the confidence of the Australian economy and the Australian currency. That in turn puts further pressure on the exchange rate, which in turn puts further upwards pressure on interest rates if the Government is seeking to maintain the exchange rate without letting it fall too much. So we have had a further indictment of the Government's policies, really, by the international marketplace and those who judge and watch carefully developments in Australia on the economic front.

The implications of these developments have been very severe indeed. Of all sections of the Australian community that have suffered, I believe that two stand out. The first is the Australian family, and particularly the single income family with young children. I believe that never in the history of this country has economic policy so adversely impacted upon families in this country. I will come back to that later on in my remarks, because one of the essential thrusts of the alternative policy proposals that the coalition is putting to the Australian people, and will be putting shortly at the forthcoming election, is a policy which recognises the fundamental role, significance and importance of the family in Australian life and also recognises the way in which families have been bled dry by the policies of this Government-not just in a direct sense but also in the flow-on impact of the policies themselves. I believe the family has been the sector in our community that has been most adversely affected by the policies and actions of this Government.

Running that section of the community a very close second-and the two are often interrelated, of course-is the small business sector. The 750,000 small businesses in Australia constitute its economic lifeblood. Many small businesses are now paying well in excess of 20 per cent for their borrowed funds. Indeed, the prime rate for business interest rates is now 20.5 per cent. For most small businesses, the actual rate that they would be paying is considerably higher than that. That is an absolutely crippling burden when one takes into account that, for many of them, business is increasingly slow and, therefore, they are left with higher stock levels that have to be financed. That is added to by the lower sales which are occurring for many of them.

It is not just the less well managed small businesses that are being hit to leg by the interest rate policy; it is also the excessive concentration by this Government on monetary policy to the exclusion of everything else. The reason for that is that the Government has not got the courage or fortitude to take the necessary decisions in relation to budgetary policy. It is the puppet of the trade union movement in relation to wages policy. Therefore, the Government is trying to fight the economic management battle with 1 1/2 arms tied behind its back. That is the fundamental problem and failure of this Government in terms of not only economic and wages policy but also all those other areas of micro-economic reform that need to be put in place if this country is going to become more productive and competitive, which is the sine qua non of any further increase in living standards in this country.

The Government is not prepared, able or willing, or allowed by its masters in either the trade union movement or elsewhere, to take the necessary steps. That lack of ability to take the necessary micro-economic reforms and macro-economic policy decisions which will allow this country to grow and be more productive is having an enormous impact on small business. As I said, it is not just the less well managed small businesses that are suffering. Most small businesses are highly leveraged. The very nature of small businesses means that they have to be normally highly geared. Because they need the money for expansion, they do not have the same calling on an equity base that larger companies have. So they need money for expansion, including in an expansionary phase new plant and equipment, even if it is leased, increased stock levels and the like.

I thought it was ominous that today a spokesman for the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd, in charge of lending for small business, quite unequivocally said that if interest rates continue at their present level it is inevitable that there will be many small business bankruptcies over the next six months. Those small business bankruptcies will be laid inevitably, indisputably and unarguably at the door and the feet of this Government.

The problems facing Australia are not new, but they are getting worse. They are not unknown: we have known them for a long time. Some of them are outlined very succinctly in what I believe is a very important report that was presented in July to the Government by a committee reviewing the export market development assistance scheme, commonly known as the Hughes report after Professor Helen Hughes, who was the chairman of the committee. As we know, she is Professor of Economics at the Australian National University. Without by any means endorsing her committee's prescriptions for the future, I believe that some things that that committee has said about the problems facing Australia are very important. I will read into the record of this debate some of those matters. The summary of the report initially points out:

The growth of Australia's external trade has accelerated since the late 1970s, but except for two years following the depreciation of the Australian dollar in 1985 and 1986, imports have exceeded exports.

The gap between imports and exports (and the even larger difference in the current account) has been financed by capital inflows with a consequent growth of external debt and debt servicing liabilities. Growing trade deficits in 1989, despite high commodity prices, culminating in a large trade deficit-
not current account deficit-
of nearly $1 billion in May 1989-
and that figure has remained at that sort of magnitude-
(with a current account deficit of $1.8 billion)-
again, we have had that; indeed, in some recent months we have been doing well if we have had a deficit of only $1.8 billion, which is unbelievable-
have brought balance of payments issues to the forefront of the political debate.
The report then goes on to say:

The trade and current account deficits, and the ensuing level of external debt are not, however, the critical issues. A country as potentially wealthy as Australia can afford to use capital inflows, provided it does so by design and for productive purposes. This has not been the case. The growing external debt reflects our unwillingness to take the measures that would enable us to export as much as we need to cover the imports the economy requires for a high standard of living. It also reflects Australia's low propensity to save.

The report then goes on to talk about the relationship between macro-economic policies and micro-economic measures in changing a community's propensity to export and to save. It makes what I believe is a very important statement because, whilst micro-economic reform is very important, we are running the risk in this country of giving it publicity and attention to the exclusion of the dreadful macro-economic performance that is occurring under this Government. The Hughes report says:

Macroeconomic policies are as important as microeconomic measures in changing a community's propensity to export and to save. Macroeconomic management is the principal influence on the price of foreign exchange. The price of foreign exchange is in turn the main policy determinant of the level of exports for all but a handful of specialized exporters whose sales are little affected by price. Australian macroeconomic policy needs major changes to stimulate exports and savings.
Subsequently it states:

Macroeconomic policies are by far the most important determinants of exports. The rate of exchange dominates the profitability of exports but, except in the short run, the rate of exchange is largely the outcome of all of a country's principal policies-fiscal, monetary, trade, and income-and how they mesh together.

The whole tenor of that report is that we are not doing too well on either the macro or micro side. Treasurer Keating, though, was going to be the great micro-economic reformer. He had a bitter fight, we all recall, with Senator Button over who was going to control the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC). He saw it as his power base to lead him to becoming king of micro-economic reform. That was two years ago. What has happened in those two years? Absolutely nothing. To my knowledge, the Treasurer has not taken one initiative through the IAC in the last two years to fulfil his commitment to do something about micro-economic reform.

The IAC has been left virtually to rot, with temporary appointments at the last legal moment to vacant commissioner positions. We are now told in this Budget that the IAC is to be totally revamped. Some other commissions and committees are to be incorporated into it. The Treasurer has now made five references to the IAC, but he has not even drafted the legislation to revamp the IAC in the way in which he said in the Budget that he would do. There are some real indications that the Government is having considerable problems in drafting that necessary legislation, particularly in so far as it relates to the bringing into a new industries commission, the revamped body, of the Inter-State Commission.

That is another example of the shoddiness of Government decision making. Decisions are being taken on the run. They are being made without any careful analysis, not only of the concepts behind the decisions, but of the particularity of their implementation. We have a classic example at the moment of a government in disarray-I believe a government in decay-and certainly a government that has run off the rails in its decision making and which does not know where to go.

If ever we wanted an example of that, we need only look at the decision today by the Government to provide $36m-$12m a year over a three-year period-to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd in the form of a production bounty. I believe that there is no conceivable justification for that decision. Indeed, I believe that Senator Button feels the same way because, in Question Time today, in response to questions about this matter, he made some quite extraordinary statements. He admitted that the Kodak decision was not consistent with the Government's overall industry policy. He said that it was different from other industry assistance decisions and it was different from the initial proposals that the Government had in mind earlier. When he attempted to explain why it was different, he made such points as the fact that Kodak (Australasia) has a marketing franchise from Eastman Kodak for the Asian area and that if this decision were not taken in the way that the Government had taken it, we would lose corporate tax, Asian markets, personnel and exports.

He said that there was no other Australian company in a similar position. That is simply incorrect. Many Australian companies have the capacity, skills and technology to increase exports. If they have problems doing that, I wonder whether the Government will be as generous to those companies as it is to Kodak. Of course, the answer is no, it will not. Why was this decision made in regard to Kodak? I believe there is only one answer, that is, that Kodak until very recently was in the electorate of Wills, the electorate of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Most of the employees of Kodak live in that electorate.

The Kodak decision today is a classic example of all the worst features of bad government decision-making. It fits in an in- creasing series. The handling of the pilots dispute has been nothing short of criminal. The pay-out to the airlines to keep them running is really a sop, firstly, to the Australian Council of Trade Unions, in a desperate attempt to keep the accord intact-an accord which has been at great cost to the Australian community-and, secondly, to keep in with the Prime Minister's great mate, Sir Peter Abeles. Those decisions are beyond the comprehension of most Australians. Similarly, I refer to the Government's decision regarding the Reserve Bank's deal with the major trading banks in order to keep down housing interest rates. The banks have been bribed to do that by way of a pay-out to them of, in effect, $150m to $200m.

We have seen the unbelievable, incomprehensible decision in relation to Coronation Hill. Virtually no commentator in the land has not picked up the idiocy of the Government's Coronation Hill decision, in light of our balance of payments problems. This area is said to be worth about $7 billion in potential mineral export income. The Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) mined the area during the 1950s and 1960s and it wishes to mine it again, mainly for gold, but for other minerals as well. That would provide us with a major increase in additional export income. The Government has taken a decision not to allow that to go ahead, despite a promise by the Prime Minister not to vary the arrangements which were decided by the Government in 1986, when the Prime Minister wrote to the Managing Director of BHP, Mr Brian Loton, in the following terms:
I can assure you there has been no change in Government policy on the conservation zone concept or in relation to Coronation Hill.
He broke that promise. Only 12 months ago the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, said that the mine would go ahead. He said:
There's not much point speculating about Coronation Hill not getting the go ahead. At this stage of the game I'd have thought most people in the Government see it going ahead . . .

As recently as July this year Senator Richardson, the responsible Minister, said that the odds were several million to one that the project would go ahead. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the Senate's attention to an estimated amount of $11.5m which is to be expended as part of the Commonwealth-Tasmania forest industry compensation package under the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. My fellow senators may or may not recall that a total package of some $50m was committed by the Federal Government to Tasmania. This amount was actually divided into four parts.

SPEECH.PARA: The first was $30m towards the establishment of plantations and was payable over five years or $6m per annum. The second was $5m committed to training programs for forest industries, also payable over five years or $1m per annum. The third part was $7m in the form of compensation payable directly to sawmills and veneer mills. This amount is payable over three years giving an amount of $2.3m per annum. The fourth part-and this is the interesting one-was an amount of $8m payable to the Forestry Commission to cover its sunk costs for such things as roads built into the southern forests area. This amount was immediately payable and was, indeed, expended in the last financial year.

What happened to that $8m? That $8m was paid to the State Government which promptly put it into the Consolidated Revenue Fund rather than writing off some of the Forestry Commission debt. It is interesting because this debt has been a subject of some discussion and debate by conservationists who frequently pointed out that this debt surely should be the basis for increased forestry royalties. What has the Government done? It has taken this money and used it for ordinary purposes of government. I wonder whether that sort of behaviour could jeopardise future Commonwealth payments to Tasmania for specific purposes.

While we consider that the greening of Australia's Government is costing the taxpayer a lot of money, it is interesting to note that the financial assistance for the management of the Tasmanian World Heritage areas is estimated to cost $5.471m this financial year, which is more than twice the amount expended last year.

If we look at the general Budget surplus estimated by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), we see that this will be severely diminished as a result of a number of recent events or unbudgeted payments. We now have new items, a payment to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd of $36m and to the airline industry of $100m plus, depending on the duration of the strike.
