We are told that the strike is over but that the compensation is still continuing. An amount of $41m is to be paid to the pharmacists. All of these payments will whittle away the estimated Budget surplus and we are not even half way through the financial year. A further number of companies have friends in the Federal Government and some companies could find themselves in financial difficulty this year and seek Federal Government compensation.

Less than two years ago we saw the situation of Christopher Skase appealing to the Federal Government for increased television coverage legislation. The Federal Government agreed to his request and had it not been for the combined effect of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats that wider coverage would now have been law. This raises another interesting point. This Federal Government has been very slow to pick up many of the misdemeanours that have been highlighted as a result of the decline in some share prices and some notable crashes recently. I draw the Senate's attention to the need for urgent action by the Commonwealth and by the States, for example, to amend the law in relation to unpaid premiums on company shares. Considerable doubt exists in the legal fraternity as to whether an unpaid premium could be claimable in the event of a liquidation. The Herscu-Hooker fiasco has raised some doubt in the legal fraternity's mind as to whether the uncalled or unpaid capital is available to creditors in the event of a liquidation. These issues must certainly be remedied at an early opportunity.

The Government should be moving also in the area of interest payments. The Government is well aware of the reason for the massive increase in our overseas debt. Much of that has been to finance company takeovers. Had we a simple corporate law that required for any major acquisition that there be a 1 : 1 debt equity ratio-or 100 per cent-there would be less reliance on highly geared companies borrowing money. There would be less of the Hooker and Skase types of fiascos in Australia. A simple amendment, a logical amendment, a prudential amendment is all that is required. But this Government is not interested in the prudential safety and security of Australian companies. It is only interested in looking after its mates and in making political points. I just mentioned those as a number of neglected areas that I think are a disgrace to this Senate, to this Parliament and to other parliaments around the States in that they continue to ignore the unsavoury happenings in the commercial world and are blind to their consequences. They refuse to take adequate measures to stop these sorts of practices, practices that tend to limit our exposure to foreign debt problems.

Australian businesses are our only economic hope. Yet the Federal Government seems determined to make life as difficult as possible for them. The Federal Government has shown a complete lack of understanding of business operations. In fact, when the Government introduced its 85 per cent company tax payable within 15 days of the close of the financial year there had been a complete absence of preconsultation with industry on these matters. We are told that the Government regularly consults before embarking on such massive issues of tax change. True, it has a tax consultative committee. It was not consulted. It is also understood that only a minimum of consultation with Treasury and the finance Department or even with the Australian Taxation Office or the Reserve Bank of Australia took place on the implications of those proposed changes. In other words, a small group or clique have gone in on their own, in their own way, without adequate background or knowledge of how business operates. It is not surprising that this Government has displayed a complete lack of understanding of business operations.

Let me now dwell on this 85 per cent of the tax bill to be paid within 15 days of the close of the financial year. We have been given a hint-I will say no more than that-that there could be changes to the definition of small companies, that they may not qualify for this very tight payment of 85 per cent within 15 days. But unless the Government gets the appropriate legislation up very quickly it has forgotten the implications of the effect of substituted accounting periods. The operative date will not be 15 July; it will be very much earlier.

However, the Government has forgotten about the implications of substituted accounting periods and just assumes that the operative date will be 15 July. If the Government had an ounce of accounting sense and had consulted Mr Boucher or anyone else in the Australian Taxation Office it would have known that many companies have substituted accounting periods, which will bring forward very dramatically the effect of that payment. Yet, there is no legislation to cover this and no definition of a small company. The Government is bereft of any understanding of the implications of the laws that it intends to pass. It is about time it consulted with and took advice from people in its own offices, its own departments, or even in the professions.

Let us consider this requirement of companies having to pay 85 per cent of their tax bill within 15 days of the close of the financial year. For many, having paid their final 1988-89 tax instalment, two years will virtually be pulled into one. This applies to those companies which are not on a substituted accounting period. This will have the effect of increasing the corporate tax rate almost back to 47 per cent. I find this quite strange because the Government recently reduced the company tax rate, and got a lot of glorification for what it had done. However, the effect of this at a time when the Government is trying to reduce excess demand was to increase consumer spending. Yet, by this measure, requiring companies to pay 85 per cent of their tax bill within 15 days, company investment will be reduced on the part of the corporate sector.

These measures are quite inconsistent and it demonstrates very vividly to those people who are analysing Government policy that there is no consistency or logic in the way the Government goes about its planning of tax effects on companies. The results of one action are nullified by another, and the nullification has a long term adverse impact on future investment, which is not good for a future recovery.

This measure was dreamt up by a fairly junior Treasury official, we understand, to increase the Budget surplus by a mere $2 billion, from $11 billion to $13 billion. Of course, as I have frequently pointed out to Senator Button, small businesses will be the hardest hit, as their capacity to pay is limited, especially with the disastrous effects of the pilots dispute. The flexibility of business will be severely affected as a result of the restricted cash flow that will occur at this time.

Another Bill before the Senate, the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill, will impinge rather sadly on public hospitals which face deficit budgeting and rely on overdraft accommodation, since their interest bills will be significantly increased as a result of having to meet two instalment deductions a month because their group tax payments are over $5m annually. The effect on these public bodies-that is, the impact of the double payment of pay as you earn taxation on all group employers whose group deductions exceed $5m-has not been properly thought out. Surely it would have been reasonable to exempt public benevolent institutions from these sorts of provisions. Again, where is the humanity, where is the reasonableness and where is the straight thinking in relation to this?

I refer again to this 85 per cent, 15 day problem. Large companies will be able to draw their lines of credit in such a way as to escape a formality that small companies will not get away with. The Australian Taxation Office has indicated its preparedness to seek out those firms and deny them a tax deduction for the interest paid on money to pay their taxes. The large companies will be able to go out into the marketplace and establish lines of credit long before, say, 15 July, and they will get off. The small companies which borrow the money a few days before 15 July will get caught by this penalty of not being able to write off their tax bill.

Again, small companies are getting caught while the large companies will get paid. For the smaller highly geared companies in particular, borrowing may not be an option. They will also be faced with a tax problem when they are denied the opportunity to write off the interest as a tax deduction. The only fair way to deal with this will be to allow tax deductions right across the board for all operations. In effect, that is what the Commissioner for Taxation is now doing, although in law he should not be allowing those write-offs as a tax deduction.

The impact of all these measures on business and the economy will be quite dramatic, and severe pressure will be placed both on corporations and on the wider financial markets. Not only will the financially weaker companies find it difficult to raise money but the extreme pressure for funds in such a restricted time interval will put added pressure on interest rates-a factor which the Government has neglected. Again, there is the problem of small businesses not being able to find qualified accounting personnel in public practice for their external auditors, to get the necessary statements finalised and the tax paid within such a small time interval.

I repeat my earlier claim about this complete lack of a plan or a program to get the whole business taxation measure into a sophisticated plan which is understood. I also draw attention to the lack of pre-consultation with industry and the lack of pre-consultation with senior Treasury and Department of Finance officers, and even the Australian Taxation Office and the Reserve Bank of Australia. All these measures signify that we have a tired government which is grasping at straws and grabbing every extra marginal dollar it possibly can from the taxpayer. After all, the last package of superannuation Bills was primarily about getting an extra $1 billion into the Budget-and it was very successful. Very few people realised the wider implications of that, because we got caught in all the hype about the different types of funds and the consequences flowing from pre-1985 profits and so on. Australia is in a dangerous position. We are on a knife edge so far as our international reputation is concerned in relation to borrowing. Yet this Government, through its recent enactments, has shown a complete inability to plan, to direct and to consult.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 1989-90 Budget details a number of programs for women. I want to take the opportunity in this debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1989-90 and cognate Bills to discuss the status of women in our society in general and, as a specific aspect of this, the matter of child-care provision and the threat that that is under from the Opposition's cynical vote-grabbing exercise whereby promises are being made but commitment is lacking. I will come in a minute to the question of trying to disentangle from the mass of confused promises or threats from Opposition spokesmen what their policy really is. It is a difficult process, requiring a clear head and a steady nerve-and I think I have both of those tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to talk about the issue of child-care and its place on the national political agenda. I do not want to make this another `my promises are bigger than your promises' speech; I would rather talk about the basic philosophies underlying the Government's approach and the Opposition's approach. I have been made very apprehensive by the whole attitude of the Opposition to child-care provision. I can only hope that those opposite never have the chance to get their hands on our children's services program. If they ever had the chance to change it, I believe the changes they would make would bear little resemblance to the promises being thrown around now.

Child-care would be a very low priority for a coalition government. What it would do with child-care would relate partly to the low priority it would give it within its overall economic program once the election was over and it was safe from the army of women voters. Equally, it would be dictated by its whole philosophically conservative approach to women and the work force. In other words, its treatment of child-care would be ideologically motivated, just as the Government's treatment of child-care has been ideologically motivated. But what a difference in ideology and what a different view of the place women have in the Australian society. Child-care is not an isolated issue. It means little to consider it in isolation from a consideration of the general position of women in our society. I do not believe that it is possible to have a proper commitment to child-care if a proper commitment to the rights of women does not exist. As far as I can see, this commitment to the rights of women does not exist within the Opposition parties.

Women have always worked outside the home. Women worked before the Industrial Revolution, during it and since it. From time to time during wars-most recently during the Second World War-they carried a large part of the burden of keeping the economy going in industry and agriculture. What is changing now is that at last there is some official recognition of the role that women play in our society. There is some formalising of that role. In the bad old days women were expected to carry the responsibility, but at the same time they were expected to be invisible while doing it, to fill gaps in the work force and to withdraw when required, as happened after the war.

Members of the National Party, in particular, still have a view of the role of women which was formed after the war when heavy propaganda was directed at women to force them out of the work force. Their perception is stuck in the 1950s. They have a misty-eyed vision of a mother in a faded but crisp print dress, waiting by the white picket fence, with her rosy-faced children clustered around her, for father to get home from a busy day doing men's work. Mother puts the tea on the table and the family sits down together. Mother says, `And how was your day, dear?', and all is right with the world. To the Nationals, any deviation from this picture is the result of some sort of conspiracy either from dreaded leftists or from even more dreaded feminists. Their view of the world is not only dated but also Anglo-Celtic. It does not accommodate the Vietnamese women working the night shift on the assembly line, the Lebanese couple working long hours in their corner shop, or a sole parent who might be supporting two or three children. This view of the world is not only not true now; it never has been true. It is a peculiarly protected middle class view of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —A myth.
—A myth, indeed. Admittedly, most members of the Liberal Party are not at this troglodyte level.
—Oh, aren't they?

—No, they are not. I will get to the honourable senator's contribution a little later. To be fair, members of the Liberal Party are at least a couple of stages further along the evolutionary path. But where is their underlying commitment to removing the barriers that prevent women from proper participation in the work force, the barriers that for so long, until the Labor Government came to office, denied us a large part of a major resource, that of female brainpower, in this country-problems which undoubtedly still exist but which are being tackled in a constructive and intelligent fashion?
—You think reverse discrimination is good, do you?

—As Senator Knowles would know, that is being done with a great deal of success. Various promises are being thrown around willy-nilly by the Opposition. I can see their superficial, though very limited, attractiveness. After all, if we accept the wildest promises of those opposite, we see that they claim to be going to commit more funds to child-care than the Government. But too much is at stake here for us to accept the razzle-dazzle from the Opposition. We must take a long, hard look at how the Opposition really feels about the role of Australian women in the work force.
—That is why you look like a bunch of stunned mullet.

—I say to the honourable senator that the feeling I have been left with since I came into the Senate in April is that those opposite have no commitment to the role of Australian women in the work force. The Liberals espouse conservative values which firmly place Australian women in the home, whether the family can afford it or not, whether the women want to be there or not. Only by understanding the Opposition's attitudes to women and their so-called rightful place can we know what value to place on what it says about child-care. Only by understanding the attitudes of Opposition members can we see the real place of child-care and other women's issues in their overall plans for our society. `Back to the Future' rules okay in the Opposition's world and women should remember this when they look at the siren's song of Opposition promises.

SPEECH.PARA: Child-care has not been an issue that I have heard spring readily to the lips of Opposition senators, at least not when there was not an election in the offing. Suddenly, the Liberal Party's opinion pollsters tell them the big news: Australian women care about child-care. That is wonderful. `Let us offer them something', say the Liberals. No wonder what they have offered has developed such cracks when the policies were developed from a position of expediency and cynicism-opinion poll driven politics again from the Liberals. Normally from Opposition senators we hear about issues such as income splitting to enable women to stay home where they belong and where, according to the Opposition, they really long to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most of them do.

—I am interested in the honourable senator's view because in this debate she spoke about what she saw as the Labor Government's social agenda and what it had led to. I do not want to, and I would not, denigrate the honourable senator in any way because I believe that she has a view of the world which is relatively benign and well meant, if, I might say, in my view-and, I am sure, in the view of the vast majority of senators-a little quaint. I think her view of the world is sociologically interesting and worth repeating. Senator Bjelke-Petersen believes that governments set social mores rather than reflect the reality of our society. In her speech, she said that Labor had directly undermined traditional family values, further threatening the stability of marriage and family life. The honourable senator believes that we have done this through equating de facto relationships with married relationships, through somehow encouraging homosexuality through government programs-although I am not sure what programs she was referring to-and by that dreaded old chestnut of discriminating against single income families in the tax system, forcing both parents in an increasing number of families out to work.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish that members of the Opposition would get out and talk to women about why they are in the work force. Certainly, some of them are there for financial reasons. They are in the work force because they must work to make ends meet or because modern community expectations mean that they want certain things for their families that would be unobtainable on one income. I do not think it is productive to try to separate the two motivations. We certainly do not seem to be able to retreat from this level of expectation. What does not seem to be genuinely in the Opposition's consciousness, though, is that many women-in fact, an ever-increasing number of women-work as a chosen lifestyle. They actually enjoy work. They believe that they have a contribution to make in their chosen area. They are not the flotsam and jetsam tossed around by the tide of economic events, as the Opposition would paint it. They have made a conscious choice about their lifestyle. It is the role of government to respond to this necessity or choice and to do its best to ensure as far as possible that women are not forced to make a choice between children and participating in the work force. The Labor Government has recognised this responsibility and has tackled it in a number of ways.

Child-care is not the only issue involved. Traditionally, women have been clustered in the lower end of the pay scale in jobs with no prospects and discriminated against in promotions and job classifications. The presumption on which employers felt entitled to act was that women were temporary and interchangeable employees; that they had jobs rather than careers; and that they could be treated in this light. What distinguishes the Government from the Opposition and what makes the Government's programs work is that a carefully constructed and cohesive social justice strategy has been put in place right across the wide range of issues that affect women. Child-care is one of those. This is why the Government has vigorously tackled issues of equal employment opportunity and affirmative action programs. We have moved to end institutionalised discrimination against women in the work force, both in the Commonwealth sphere and in cooperation with Labor State governments.

We have moved to increase skill levels and work force participation for women. This process started early in the life of the Labor Government with the community employment program. The community employment program successfully reintroduced many women to the work force. The main criticism that could be made of it was the lack of a formalised training component. However, our programs have gone from strength to strength and the current programs, including Newstart and jobs, education and training (JET), have assisted many women, including older women, back to a proper place in the work force. Important beneficiaries of these programs are and will continue to be women raising families on their own who, until now, have been in the social security net with the desire to get out but with no assistance to do so.

An important element of the Government's program for women is the retirement income measures contained in the Budget and the retirement income policy statement which implement the Government's objectives for superannuation for women, as outlined in the National Agenda for Women. These measures will significantly increase both the number of women who will have superannuation coverage and the adequacy of that coverage. For the first time, allowances will be made for the fact that women have to take time off for childbearing and often work part time for periods when they have young children. This is the way that the Government sees its responsibility to women. I contrast that with the way the Opposition sees its responsibility to women, as outlined in its so-called Fair Go for Women statement. With respect to the statement, the National Women's Consultative Council said:
The statement does not give any recognition to implementation of the National Agenda for Women . . .
Specifically on child-care, the Council said:
The rebate of $20 per week falls far short of any realistic recognition of the costs of child care but it will be sued to lessen government commitment to the children's services program.

If we read what Mr Connolly, the Opposition spokesman for social security, had to say in what could be described as a remarkably frank and honest interview in the Sydney Morning Herald of 23 October, we see that these concerns are very well-founded. I will quote a little from the article that was so embarrassing for the Opposition which does not want any of these matters to surface before the election. The first quote reads:
These funding measures, which will effectively privatise child care except for the needy, are certain to be strongly opposed by the child care lobby and women's groups.

The article points out that these measures were not outlined when the Opposition officially outlined its family package. Of course, they were not! I ask what honourable senators think about the next quote from the article, which reads:
Mr Connolly also revealed that under a coalition government middle income families would not be allowed into government child care centres.
What a surprise! How about the next quote for size? With respect to Liberal Government spending, Mr Connolly was reported to have said:
There will be no more money spent. It's a case of rejigging the system.

Of course, Mr Connolly was told off by the current Leader of the Liberal Party, his current boss, for his statements, but whom do we believe? There is a certain warped logic and cohesiveness to what Mr Connolly said that gives it the ring of truth. I go back to the National Women's Consultative Council's assessment of the Fair Go for Women statement. On the dependent spouse rebate, it points out that the Opposition plans to re-allocate money that the Government gives to the primary care giver. It said:

By increasing the eligibility threshold for the dependent spouse rebate, a payment primarily to men, the Economic Action Plan gives little recognition to the numbers of women re-entering the workforce and the costs incurred by them in doing so.

Mr Braithwaite, the Opposition spokesman for child-care, then also fouled it up. He promised that a coalition government would extend fee relief in private child-care centres. The proposition was never costed, or even promised or proposed in the original Opposition plan and Mr Peacock has had to beat a very hasty retreat on that one also. As to whether and how we have to factor in the Connolly and Braithwaite contributions-be they mark 1, mark 2, mark 3 or mark whatever, it is still very hard to tell. I see from the Sydney Morning Herald as recently as last Friday that the Leader of the Opposition's office was still telling the press that there was nothing in writing. I think that is a very wise move on the part of the Liberal Party to muddy the water because the more the water clears the more exposed the Opposition will be. On the other hand, the Government's children's services program is here and operating for all to see with all its glories and its faults. I would not pretend that it is perfect yet. One would like to see improvements to it and even more places than those achieved and those that have been promised. I do not want to see low and middle income earners disadvantaged in relation to fee relief when they just cannot get a place in a government funded child-care centre.

Despite those improvements that are still to come, the Government has a coherent policy that looks at the way in which women need child-care to be provided. As a consequence, it provides a range of services, namely, work related care consisting of centre-based day care, family day care, outside school hours and vacation care and multifunctional centres that are now operating in rural areas on a pilot basis. It provides occasional care and special services for a range of children with special needs, such as Aboriginal children, children of non-English speaking background or disabled children. It is a policy which, by the end of next year, will have seen the creation of approximately 100,000 new child-care places. It is a policy that aims at a good quality of child-care.
In the Age newspaper of 13 October, Dr Don Edgar of the Australian Institute of Family Studies was quoted as saying:

Overseas research on the effects of child care on children shows that those in quality day-care are `superior' in school performance, social competence and interaction to many who stay at home with friends or relatives.

I wonder about the Opposition's commitment to quality care when the Opposition spokesman on community services, Mr Braithwaite, has said that a wide range of informal child-care arrangements would attract the Opposition's tax rebate. The approach of the Government to women's issues and the pathetic approach of the Opposition to women's issues are out in the light of day. On the one hand, the Government has adopted a careful and systematic approach to removing inequities to women in our society in general and in the work force in particular. On the other hand, the Opposition has a haphazard grab bag of opportunistic and fragmented policies that hark back to the bad old days of the fist full of dollars.

I can only say to women who are making up their minds on the relative approaches of the Government and the Opposition that they should look at this Government's record and then look back to the record of the previous coalition government and examine the coalition's new promises in the light of its old record and lack of commitment to women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some months ago I was asked about what I regarded as my major political objectives. The following was my answer: to use the opportunities that are afforded by being in government to restore basic Liberal values; to redraw the boundary between what the Government should do and what people can do best for themselves, and thus foster values such as individual freedom, responsibility, excellence, respect for others and the duty to care for the genuinely needy.

SPEECH.PARA: I did not arrive at that statement of my beliefs in an idle moment. They were the culmination of my previous experience and my two years in this place during which I travelled the length and breath of my home State of Victoria and during which time I spent many hours talking to the old, the young and the in-between. One of the things that I learnt during all of that travel and all of that talk was that people are unhappy with this Labor Government because of the things that are set out in the Appropriation Bills now before the Senate. These Bills are the statement of the beliefs of the Hawke Government. They are not just numbers plucked out of the air; they are the costings, put by the Public Service, on the programs which this Labor Government has implemented. This is the burden of my argument-of the political objectives that I set as my goal.

The Hawke Government has become obsessed with a notion of managerial efficiency which finds its expression in programs and in program budgeting. In its obsession with efficiency, the Hawke Government has lost sight of the people-those ordinary people who want to be left to get on with the business of their lives without the Government poking its nose into their business. The Hawke Government has lost sight also of the people who genuinely need help. It has become so fixed with the elegance of its centrally applied solution to all problems and with what it mistakenly calls equity that it has forgotten-if it ever knew-that the person in Burnie is not the same as the person in Broome; that the needs and resources of Melbourne are not those of Merino or Mallacoota.

Let me cite some examples of how people are being let down by the Government's obsession with programs. One of the goals of this Government is to establish a ratio of nursing homes to hostels-of 40 nursing homes to 60 hostels per 1,000 head of population aged over 70-which is to be applied across Australia. The Hawke Government has introduced funding arrangements that have been named care aggregated module and standard aggregated module. That formula and the formula for funding have been applied across Australia. Without opposition from this side of the chamber and particular pushing by Victorian senators, the individual needs of small rural nursing homes and of bush nursing hospitals would never have been addressed. With calls from the Opposition, and from me in particular, the Government has come up with the idea of a multipurpose centre. However, that was not done until the Government was pressed into looking at the individual needs and the regional needs of people and into looking at the fact that centrally controlled programs do not meet the needs of those individuals or regions.

In their goal to set up a formula, a group of 8,000 older people in Victoria are caring for themselves in special accommodation houses. A similar group of people does not exist anywhere else in Australia. Those people receive only pension and rent assistance. They are deprived of any form of service. This Government has not addressed that issue. Home and community care funding is another issue that illustrates the point that I am trying to make. The Canberra Times of 11 June of this year carried a story that should have wrenched at the heart of every member of parliament. That was a story about a woman who was paralysed from the armpits down as a result of multiple sclerosis. Her husband, who also has multiple sclerosis, is confined to a wheelchair. He is being cared for by the woman's 76-year-old mother. The woman who has multiple sclerosis was taken to hospital. Her 76-year-old mother became ill as a result of caring for her daughter and son-in-law. As well, two younger children in the family-a 14-year-old and a 20-year-old-were pitching in to help. When the woman went to hospital she became very anxious that, when she returned home, she would be helpless and unable to care for herself because her husband would be unable to help her mother and her. That woman said:
I was told I did not qualify for attendant care under the Home and Community Care program until I had been in a nursing home for 100 days.

That says something about the flexibility and the caring of this Government. Because that woman did not fit into some sort of program, goals or whatever else, she was going to be left at home without any sort of assistance.

The Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled (ACROD) is an organisation that is concerned about that group of people that Labor so quickly tells us it looks after and that the Opposition neglects. In the title article of its newsletter of April-May 1989, ACROD said:
What happened to flexibility under the DSA?
In reply to the questions that consumers ask, ACROD went on to say:
What happened to the flexibility Don Grimes promised us so often? What happened to the emphasis on consumer outcomes rather than processes?
In relation to the Government's guidelines, it went on to say:
. . . are too restrictive in scope as they indicate that only two models would be considered eligible for funding as new services-individual jobs in open employment and small businesses.

I wonder whether some of my Victorian colleagues have visited the Horsham wool factory, which is a perfect example of a program that would not be funded under the new arrangements. It is a creative, innovative program in which young people are learning a tremendous number of skills. That factory is setting itself up in such a way that, one day, it may in fact be self-sustaining. However, at the moment it does not qualify under those two categories.
We read about homelessness, a major issue of the Burdekin report. What does Mr Burdekin have to say about Government programs and Government outcomes? He said:

The Inquiry found that the most successful models for assisting homeless children are those where the community is involved. Programs which retain children and young people in their local communities-rather than warehousing them in refuges in places like Kings Cross-offer the best chance for family reconciliation, for continuing with education and training and for avoiding the all too common slide into prostitution, crime and drugs. It was also very clear to the Inquiry that the community-with proper resourcing, co-ordination and standard-setting from government-can provide young people with a degree of personal support which State institutions seem simply unable to deliver. The inquiry, therefore, did not propose a bureaucratic `big government' model, but one in which the government offers more effective encouragement and assistance to the community to take responsibility.

I heard Burdekin speak at the Liberal Party policy assembly. Given what I think his political views were, I am sure that he has been confronted in this report, that he had to stand and look at whether government had the solutions or whether the community might have the solutions. I believe the answer to some of the soul-searching that Mr Burdekin had to come up with lies in that statement I have just quoted.

The House of Representatives committee report on the Department of Social Security, which is entitled `Fairness, Courtesy and Efficiency' talks about some of the problems that were found when a review of this area was conducted. Page 3 of that report states:
It is clear that agencies often act as a substitute-
when the report talks about agencies it refers in the main to voluntary agencies-
for the Department where problems arise. A substantial proportion of the workload of the agencies consists of assistance to DSS clients who are concerned to maintain or obtain their entitlements.

Just as I am talking about that, it struck me and my staff, when we saw an advertisement in the newspaper from the Smith Family, that the very thing that was being spoken of in the Burdekin report, or one of the reasons why local community groups could deliver the service better than maybe some Government departments, was answered in an advertisement in which the Smith Family was calling for funds. The advertisement states:

But in our long experience, the families who most need our help are often the ones who are most reluctant to ask for it. That's why each application we receive is carefully assessed on its individual merits by trained, full-time staff.
It's their responsibility to ensure not only that the need is genuine, but also that the help is constructive.

I was fascinated by this advertisement, so fascinated that I went down to meet the people at the Smith Family. The Smith Family has been operating a lot longer in New South Wales than it has in Victoria. I believed that if the Smith Family was trying to convince the public to give money and it was using as an argument that it assessed each family and that was a reason for giving the money-it was making sure it was going to those in genuine need-that was maybe what the taxpayer ought to be demanding, if the taxpayer is giving money for those in genuine need. If an organisation such as that, flat chat for funds, thinks it is worthwhile to do that sort of evaluation and it is effective in delivering a service, then I think it behoves us to look at whether organisations such as the Smith Family are the sorts of organisations that are better able to deliver the service at grassroots.

I do not want to stay on social security and welfare type issues. I want to deal with another area indicated to me in which these programs do not always work. Sometimes when the Government puts into place some fancy formula, it does not always meet the needs of individuals. I have talked a number of times in this place about the problems that the specialty cheese industry in Vic- toria-I speak only about the industry in Victoria, because I know about it-is facing with regulations that may be suitable for large exporters of cheese but are totally unacceptable and inhibit the export of specialty cheese, which is in fact an example of the very thing Australia needs-import replacement and exports. That is another example of an overall policy, a government, centrally controlled policy, that does not meet the needs at a regional level.

How did we arrive at this situation? The source of much of this failure of policy and programs to deliver effective services to those in need can be found in the restructuring of the public sector under the Hawke Government. `Managerialism' has become the administrative buzz word. To paraphrase one commentator: `efficiency and effectiveness' have replaced responsiveness and accountability.
I would like to quote the words of Jack Waterford, who said in the Australian Public Policy newsletter No. 3 of 1988:

Although the Department of Finance, in particular talks about being output oriented, it is in fact the most input oriented of all. Better management to it means nothing more than achieving the same result with less administrative resources-less inputs. Almost all of the newly developed management tools are very good at telling one the cost per head or administrative unit of providing a service; what they are far less efficient at doing is telling one whether one is getting value for money; whether the service is worthwhile anyway, or whether it ought to be improved. Efficiency, in short, is not the same as effectiveness; still less, I would argue, is it necessarily about public interest.

One explanation for this focus on managerialism has been given by Terry Carney, the associate professor of law at Monash University and the chairperson of the National Advisory Council on Social Welfare. In reviewing the effectiveness of judicial review of decisions on their merits by specialist administrative tribunals, Professor Carney has contended that `they simply put an acceptable face on the harsh content of the substantive law; a content which is shaped by the pressures of fiscal responsibility, technological convenience, and considerations of preservation of bureaucratic power.' He goes on to say:

The point [is] that rule-based remedies may do more harm than good . . . It becomes clear that rules are an especially attractive way of restricting rights in the interests of achieving fiscal restraint. The compensation recoupment saga testifies to that.

Let me give another example. I think Senator Reynolds will remember this one because I asked her about it in the Estimates committee. It relates to rights restricted in the interests of achieving fiscal restraint. Family allowances have been cut to people who live out of the country for more than three years. One group that has been particularly affected-and this group could most probably be numbered on a couple of pairs of hands, if not two hands-is a group comprising aid workers who work overseas on programs partly funded by government organisations. I can cite the instance of one family that I know of with four children who were working overseas on a medical aid program, a program which was funded by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau. The family's income is $12,000 per annum, paid out of Australia. They pay Australian taxes. That family is deprived of its family allowance. The only way in which that can be remedied is by changing the law. When I asked about it, it seemed to me that the Government really did not care. Its attitude seemed to be that it does not matter about the individual, as long as the overall program works: they are not going to vote for us, anyway. They are only a handful, so let us not worry about them. It is about the service not being delivered to meet the individual needs. That is the theme of my speech tonight.
I will refer to Carney again. He goes on to say:

But it may not have been so obvious that technological convenience presses inexorably in the same direction. This is because computerisation is perceived to be the means by which to satisfy the otherwise divergent goals of promoting bureaucratic uniformity of administration, while at the same time also achieving speedier, cheaper and more efficient decision-making. Personal judgments and individual assessments of circumstances are driven out-
that is right: driven out like the people working in Nepal-

in the rush to fashion legislation which can, in the main, be routinised (and `run' on the DSS computer). To this end the search is for the least complex formulae, based on easily established non-subjective variables; once located it is legislated into force, even if violence is done to the pre-existing rationale for that aspect of the welfare state.

Let me tell the chamber that the elderly of Victoria-that is the group that I can speak of-know what he is talking about. Even the bureaucracy is belatedly coming to recognise the faults that Professor Carney has recognised.

I quote from the Canberra Times an article called `Putting humanity back into programs', dated 14 March 1989. I thought, `This is fascinating; I must find out what this is all about'. I was interested in the theme of programs versus people and had been collecting information on it for six months. I read that a review had been done, and a document called Towards a fairer Australia-Social justice and program management: A guide had been produced to tell us how to put humanity back into programs. Is that not wonderful! The Government has printed a little book to tell us how to put humanity back into programs. I could tell it how to do it: get the service delivered and decided closer to the grassroots. The guide tells us how to find out how good is the service provided by the program. It tells us that one thing we can do is to consult, to get client feedback. I thought that was very interesting.
Only today there came into my office a paper called From Policy to Practice, by Adam Graycar, Commissioner for the Ageing. He says:
I seem to get a steady run of representations about government operating unilaterally and with insufficient consultation.

Here we have the Government telling its departments to consult and to find out how to improve the program by consulting the clients, yet the Commissioner for the Ageing is telling us that he finds that they are operating unilaterally and with insufficient consultation. He says:

Although governments try hard to consult and to be seen as consulting well, their efforts are often not treated as genuine. People with whom the government is consulting say `sure, they hold meetings, but they're not to listen, but to tell us what they believe and how things should be. Then they go and tell their Minister they've consulted.'
Those people must have been at a few of the consultations that I have been at. He says:

There is a great danger that consultation could become a one way affair, an exercise in window dressing and futility. This can happen if the authorities see their place in the Westminster system as sacrosanct, take insufficient note of the practice base, and become reluctant to share information.

I give another example: in New South Wales, under an enlightened Liberal government, the Water Board has gone even further than the Federal Government and has asked charities and community groups to help distribute $800,000 from a new hardship fund for those who genuinely need help to pay their water and sewerage bills. In so doing, the Government recognised the failure of its previous assistance schemes to get to the people who really needed help.

Amazingly, Labor Government Ministers are finally admitting that they have got things wrong. The Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), when introducing the Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill in 1989, told the House of Representatives:

The SAAP review found that the current SAAP subprograms have played an important role in the establishment phase of SAAP but suggested that the subprogram focus had created unnecessary complexity, led to restrictions which disadvantaged certain high need groups-for example, single homeless women and families-and hampered flexibility in planning and referral. It recommended the replacement of subprograms with target groups. Accordingly, under the new program, funds will be allocated within States each year according to priority target groups, rather than some subprograms.
He might have seen the light on that, but he has a long way to go yet before he sees the light fully.

The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) is quoted in the Australian Financial Review of 24 July this year as saying that the present Government has learnt from the mistakes of its predecessor, the Whitlam Government, and would not put money into building bureaucracies to oversee social initiatives. He says that an important emphasis in the new phase of policy is to design programs to fit clients better, and particularly to encourage greater flexibility in work patterns, retirement, education and training. I only wish he had extended his list to include the residents of nursing homes and aged persons hostels, who are suffering from the rigidities of the present programs in that area.

How would the coalition do things better? I give two examples from the coalition's Economic Action Plan which show how we propose in government to change the focus back to people, back to the grassroots. Taking unemployment as an example, media commentary on the unemployment policy has centred entirely on people going off the dole after nine months. I have read in the press some interviews with school children who have said how hard it would be for them to register for the dole. What sort of an attitude has the Labor Government inculcated into our young students in schools that they think like this? The Victorian Government has produced a pamphlet advising school leavers on how to register for the dole; not on how to go about getting a job and recognising the virtue of honest labour, but on how to register for the dole. Not a word about work. No wonder we have kids with that attitude.

The commentators have not bothered to read the assessment of labour market training programs in the supplementary notes on expenditure, which review the effectiveness of existing programs and their failure to achieve the objective of putting Australians to work. These schemes have been criticised by the Auditor-General, by industry groups and even by those whom one would normally expect to be Government sympathisers. The Social Welfare Research Centre at the University of New South Wales in February 1989 discussed the employment of people with disabilities. It said, in the report it produced:

One of the difficulties is that the employment market is dynamic and many of the schemes developed by governments are based on arrangements which do not reflect market conditions. For example, something like 50 per cent of the jobs created in the last decade have been part-time, yet most employment creation schemes are predicated on the notion of full-time employment. Both the market and society value part-time employment. It is respectable and it pays. It is also a form of employment which meets the needs of many people.
This is not a Liberal government saying this; this is the Social Welfare Research Centre of the University of New South Wales. It says:
Recognising the importance of part-time work in no way indicates that people aren't entitled to full-time work but it does suggest a more flexible approach for many.
The Brotherhood of St Laurence issued a study of the Government's job training scheme. Veronica Sheen, speaking on behalf of the Brotherhood, said:

The Government's programs are too simplistic and too short-sighted. They are not recognising the very severe levels of disadvantage among long-term unemployed people who vary from homeless teenagers to single mothers and older sole parents who have not worked and are very nervous about it.

The coalition plan quite clearly indicates that those schemes which have proved to be effective will be retained and supported. People without jobs will be expected to undertake training to make them employable. Even more importantly, delivery of the training and employment schemes will be handed back to where it can be most effective. I quote from the Economic Action Plan:

Of particular importance in making these schemes more relevant will be the ability to permit state governments and community groups to manage them, to allow privatisation in contracting out, and the implementation of our community service for unemployment benefits program. Job creation schemes, as distinct from genuine training programs, will be curtailed.

Child-care is another area where we will see greater flexibility, despite what Senator Faulkner said this evening. Under the current Government schemes, families with an income of up to around $38,000 are entitled to a sliding scale of fee relief for child-care. Coalition policy will not change this. Of course, under this Government, if parents use private child-care centres or informal arrangements, there is no fee relief. To be eligible for fee relief, in other words, families must accept that the style of care for which the Government provides a subsidy is a style appropriate to their child or children; there is no choice. All children have different needs-each child can have different needs at different times of his or her life-and parents are the best people to make the judgment of what a child needs, not the Government. Coalition policy will provide the flexibility to allow parents to make these choices in the best interests of the family.

Informal child-care arrangements that qualify for child-care rebates would include any arrangement which is legal. For instance, any private arrangements which comply with State law would qualify where a parent requires child-care to enable her or him to work. It is interesting, in the light of the Government's criticism of the coalition's policy as giving to those who are not in need, to go back to the interview with Social Security Minister Howe in the Australian Financial Review last July. Mr Howe is quoted as supporting a strengthened welfare state. The report says that his idea is that the Government does not merely provide income and services for low income earners, but that all people have a right to some level of government service and program to counteract their family problems. It said that Mr Howe recognised that the new phase of social policy would have to be within the Government's tight budgetary framework, but he believed that politically now was the time to offer the electorate a bit more hope for the future. That is exactly what the coalition's Economic Action Plan is doing with its child-care package.

Let us look at the values the Government has established in the economic and social program being funded through these appropriations. The Government's values are those of a nanny state-of making someone else take the responsibility for our lives and how we live them; of stifling excellence in the name of equity; of fostering dull uniformity rather than rejoicing in diversity; of devaluing others, especially those who voluntarily service their families and communities; of offloading onto the taxpayer much of our individual responsibility to help those less well off than ourselves. We must turn to the question of why the coalition's action plan has been so well received. It is because the community in its broadest sense feels that it is time to restore the basic values I outlined at the beginning of my remarks, that it is time to redraw the boundaries between what government can and should do and what people can do best for themselves. It is time once more to foster values such as individual freedom, responsibility, excellence, respect for others and the duty to care for the genuinely needy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1989-90 and cognate Bills I propose to talk mostly about the areas of industrial relations and wealth creation. This Budget is impressive indeed when measured against Budgets brought down by previous Liberal-National Party governments. It has for its purpose the short term goal of maintaining living standards, at least to the extent possible, with particular emphasis, as in the past, on the needs of the disadvantaged, the lower paid workers and those on fixed incomes. This is achieved through an enhanced social wage, a universal health scheme, increased pensions, more and better training and education for the semi-skilled, increased minimum wages in awards and new career path opportunities. No civilised society can ignore its disadvantaged people and not seek to uplift them, to provide for them the opportunity to play a more important and a more constructive role in society.

SPEECH.PARA: All of us in this place, on both sides, want to see a happy, fulfilled society-well educated, healthy, trained and involved in productive work or at a productive calling. It is true that we have different ideas as to how we as a nation should go about this task and the goals we should set ourselves on the road to that achievement. But there can be no argument with any validity which does not recognise that we must create wealth in the form of commodities and services to provide for community needs. Without such community wealth it is not possible to finance education, health, communications, transport, social security payments and other services which must be financed from our national product. That is not to say that the Government has to provide them but they must be provided from our national product. However, I believe that the Government has a role to provide those services.

This Government has a clear attitude and a record which demonstrates that it differs greatly from the Opposition on the questions of the method of wealth creation and the division of that wealth amongst the Australian people. Past coalition governments have presided over periods of the `lucky country' syndrome, the era of confrontation between capital and labour expressed popularly as `them and us'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who led all that?

—The people Senator Panizza represents established that-the servant and master relationship and the use of the Army and the troops against the shearers in 1890 in Barcaldine. They put people in gaol for sticking up for their rights and wanting to belong to a union and have decent wages. The people Senator Panizza represents-the Liberal and National parties-are responsible.

SPEECH.PARA: This Labor Government, when in opposition, set about making an agreement with the organised trade union movement to provide for rationalisation of industrial relations, wages stability, industrial safety and health, plans to encourage higher productivity, and the opportunity for workers through their trade unions to achieve greater equity in the work environment. Building on this firm base, when the Australian Labor Party came to office it activated plans to assist important industries such as steel. The Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) threatened to get out of steel because it said it was getting a return of 2 per cent. In car manufacturing there were far too many models and manufacturers. Even they have now come to that conclusion and have consolidated in many ways. We can look also at the heavy engineering package and the textiles, clothing and footwear package.

In the process of assisting these industries the previously agreed position of the trade unions was most important-the transfer of wages to profit to ensure finance for companies which should then have invested such profits in modern machinery, research and development in Australia. I repeat that there was an agreement, and unions accepted depressed wages to allow more profits to accrue to employers to allow for increased investment. More work and greater prosperity in the community would have followed. Some employers took the opportunity and made those investments; other employers did not. It some cases employers invested their money overseas and imported the products of other countries. There was a clear breach of faith by some.

The trade unions did not take their bat and ball home but persevered. The trade unions, in the knowledge that Australia was no longer a lucky country but in the different and difficult position of a small economy in a large world economy, saw the need to become efficient in a way that we had not done before. Interest in management policy and direction was very important to them. In the past unions had allowed management to run its own race. If it wanted to be in-efficient and closed, workers got other jobs under the old lucky country syndrome. This was no longer possible under the changed circumstances, and trade unions began to take an interest in the way that factories and workplaces were run, because if the workplace or factory closed workers lost their jobs and their ability to provide in the best way they could for their families.

A demonstration of the good faith of the trade unions and the efficient way in which they went about their work was the heavy engineering package. Workers were very keen to talk to employers and with the Heavy Engineering Board which was carrying out the process to convince employers to upgrade their machinery, to look at changed work methods and to become more efficient. But in many cases employers were not knowledgeable enough-in some cases it appeared to border on stupidity-to be able to take advantage or seek to take advantage of that package. Others did take advantage of it and sought to use it as a prop for inefficiencies of the past and the present.

The trade unions were not interested in such a proposal and neither was this Labor Government. The Labor Government did everything it could in that area. As I recall, it provided a package at that time of $130m. I think some $30m was not spent because the employers were so ineffective and so inefficient that they were not able to make use of it. The trade union movement is often accused of being bloody-minded and it is often said that the Labor Party panders to the trade union movement, but let me go back to the steel package. A lot of new technology was introduced by BHP. In fact, its agreement to invest in machinery and change work methods was far exceeded as it progressed down the path. BHP invested many millions of dollars more than it had intended to. The bottom line is that its profit, according to its information, has gone from 2 per cent to in the area of 15 per cent.

What, on the other hand, has occurred in the trade union movement, the ranks of the workers in that industry? Tens of thousands of workers have lost their jobs. Were they happy? No, they were not; they were very unhappy. There was some industrial disputation about the matter but finally they have accepted the position that at least there are still many thousands of jobs in the steel industry, a very virile and good industry which contributes to the local economy by way of manufactured goods that are also import replacements and also by getting into the export trade.

To my knowledge, BHP has been one of the worst companies in terms of industrial relations. However, I was in a state of shock when I talked to people from the company on one occasion in one of our Caucus committees and found that they had changed their whole attitude and that they were seeking to develop better work relationships. It appears that in many cases they have been able to achieve that: industrial relations have improved. To show the importance of the package that has been put together by the trade unions and the Labor Government with regard to training, I point out that on the occasion of the visit to BHP the management said to us that in one of the rolling mills it needed to reduce its staff from 20-odd people down to four or five as a result of increased technology and the use of computers. Management said that it very much wanted to give the opportunity of continued employment to people in that particular section but it was not able to because the people had not been given the type of education that would allow them to be retrained. So management had to bring in new people and retrench the total work force in that area, which was something that it did not want to do. I make that point to emphasise the importance of the policy of the Labor Government with regard to training.

If one looks at what is contained in the Budget and what the Government is seeking to do, we find that $12m has been allocated to the workplace reform program in the area of restructuring. This program will help with the process of change within the workplace. Specifically, the program will establish a network of workplace resource centres to provide expertise on a range of issues involved with bringing about award restructuring; provide work change assistance for projects bringing about award restructuring; and provide work training to enlarge the pool of specialists skilled in industrial relations and workplace participation and practice. The Government is not just saying to companies, `Get off your backside and train people. You change your work practices and upgrade your management skills'. The Government is saying, `You should do these things, but we will help you', and it has provided $12m in the Budget for that. The program is a good example of the Government's tripartite approach to bringing about micro-economic change. Government, workers and management are developing specific strategies and processes for change.

The Affirmative Action Agency, which was covered to some extent by Senator Faulkner, has received $1.643m. The Agency will continue to carry out the affirmative action program. Worksafe Australia has received, in round figures, $20m to achieve a healthy and safe working environment. The total operating budget for the Department of Industrial Relations is $43.6m with key initiatives being the extension of workplace reform programs. It will encompass the establishment of a network of workplace resource centres where expertise in human resource management, industrial relations and production planning and design will be available on a commercial basis for enterprises involved in improving efficiency and competitiveness through the award restructuring process. Five centres are due to open shortly. Again, that is a very clear demonstration that the Government is not just saying, `Look, you do that, we are not going to help. We think it is up to you'. The Government is weighing in with this sort of money to assist employers to come to the realisation that, by acquiring the skills to bring about those changes in the workplace and in work restructuring, the whole of our community will benefit.

Recently, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Peter Morris, addressed the Australian Council of Trade Unions Congress. He made the point that the programs were designed to help achieve a competitive, efficient and flexible labour market. No honourable senator on the other side of the chamber could argue with that. I think that is what they want; I have heard them talk about it. The Minister also made the point that the programs were designed to provide and maintain an industrial relations system which is fair to all parties. I would hope that that is what honourable senators on the other side of the chamber want. I am not encouraged to believe that, hearing some of the utterances. The Minister said that the programs were designed to promote fair wages and conditions for all workers while assisting Australia's economic performance and to fulfil the Government's responsibilities as an employer to ensure fair and responsible treatment of its work force. The Minister went on to say that 1.5 million new jobs had been created. Over half of those have been filled by women, largely because of the discipline of trade unionists who realise that the biggest improvement to people's living standards can be achieved only through useful and productive work. I have heard honourable senators on the other side of the House talk about useful and productive work. It sounds like some sort of a compromise government, does it not?

The Minister said that inflation had been cut significantly under the Government as a result of restraint and responsibility exercised by trade unionists. The Minister made the point that the Government's social justice strategy had helped the low paid and those outside the official work force to cope with the difficult period of economic adjustment. We have increased family assistance and cut taxes to ensure that those less well off in our community have improved protection-that is, that the tax cuts went to the lower paid workers. The spread of superannuation in Australia has improved people's security during retirement. The Minister said that for the first time, men and women in the work force were entitled to superannuation benefits with a contribution from their employer and that this had particularly helped the lower paid worker.

Even though there have been superannuation schemes in existence in this country for many years, most of them were designed in such a way that either the workers never got anything out of them and the fund could legally be used by the employer and was retained in his possession or people, when they transferred from one job to another, were not able to take with them the benefits of that superannuation scheme, beyond that which they may have contributed themselves. Of course, under the policy of this Labor Government, in cooperation with the trade unions, that has changed and now there is good portability where people can go from one job to another and maintain their superannuation rights and not lose their entitlements. The vesting is there to protect people.

The Minister went on to say that great emphasis had been placed on education and training and that this had led to a vast expansion of training opportunities since 1983, especially for young people. The new training guarantee scheme is designed to keep up the momentum and ensure that industry pays its fair share. My experience over many years in the trade union movement was that I found a number of employers were excellent trainers and had a great conviction about the need to have trained and skilled people in the work force coming on so that industry could be well served and people were proud of the skills that they developed and were able to use. But there are lousy employers who are only in business to maximise their profits. They always waited until someone was trained by another employer and then stole those employees by offering a bit of additional money. In many cases, they did not keep them very long because of their employment record. The Government's proposition is that those who do not want to train are not forced to, but they should contribute to those who do. Those people who finance training in an equitable way would not be required to spend any more than they do at the current time. It could well be less.

The Minister also made the point that sex discrimination and affirmative action legislation has given new and greater opportunity to women in the work force. The legislation has now been given real substance with new skills and career paths. The legislation makes it very clear that the restructuring of awards takes into account the right of women to be trained and to take up positions in the work-place as they desire and wish. The establishment of Worksafe Australia has led to national standards for occupational health and safety. One of the things that one can look at to really understand the need that has existed for so many years is the way in which asbestos was considered to be no threat to health but is now realised to have caused the deaths of many people, the most famous case, of course, being Wittenoom Gorge where the asbestos was actually put on the school ground. I am not suggesting for one moment that some of those people really understood what they were doing. I know what they were told, and I have seen the evidence. So there is a need for Worksafe Australia, and it plays a very important role.

The Minister said that the 1984 termination, change and redundancy decision protected and involved workers in changes affecting them at the workplace. It was a decision which brought Australia into one of the most advanced democratic societies. Of course, if people must lose their jobs and become redundant, and it is to the benefit of society, as a result of possibly cheaper commodities and a more efficient industry, they should not bear the total brunt. If it is of benefit to the community, the community should be prepared to contribute to the payment of compensation for those lost jobs and opportunities.

Finally, the Minister pointed out that the rate of industrial dispute was less than half the level of the previous Government. In 1982, the time lost per 1,000 workers throughout Australia was 2.2 days. In the financial year 1986-87, it was 1.1 days per 1,000 workers. The Government supports the centralised wage fixing system and equity for workers, while at the same time using whatever legitimate means are available to increase productivity and community wealth. However, in the Opposition's policy paper on award restructuring, issued by Mr Reith, it is stated:

. . . changes to traditional notions of standard hours . . . over periods such as a month or a year, rather than a week, with a high degree of flexibility in allocating work hours within the stated period . . .

Under the proposal, one would live only in order to work, with the employer deciding when one is going to work. Those sorts of conditions will never be accepted by workers who, in the main, are gregarious and like to work together within certain hours and play sport, and pursue social activities together, in their leisure time. They do not want a system in which half of them are at work and half are at home. They do not want their leisure time or time in which they can use education facilities dictated to them in that way.

Mr Reith suggests that the work force, the people in the community, subject themselves to these arrangements in the best interests of employers. He suggests that employers introduce specialist weekend shifts, with employee consent provisions as part of the package. Of course, that consent will not be forthcoming. He also suggests the removal of the eight hour a day limit on ordinary working hours which may be worked. This would allow, for example, 12-hour shifts. This flies in the face of all industrial relations experience at the workplace. It would take us back to the early part of the century when mining companies expected people to work for 50 hours a week. They found that if they reduced that to 44 hours a week, they got just as much production out of them because people had a higher rate of productivity. If one wants to read about such experiences, one needs only to look at Australia's . . . Awakening written by W. G. Spence in which he outlines his experiences at a mine in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —A classic, too.

—Yes. The Opposition's proposal flies in the face of all our experiences. It suggests a return to the situation that prevailed earlier in the century. Mr Reith may have forgotten to include one point: he may want to put the children back in the mines. He must have made a mistake when he omitted that. He refers in his paper to the spread of hours. Already, trade unions have agreed to some increase in the spread of hours. I think the figure they have agreed to is an extra two hours, from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m., whereas the agreed spread of hours used to be from 7 a.m. to 5.30 p.m. So at least they have accommodated that suggestion. The organised trade union movement is looking at a number of other possibilities that will accommodate the needs of employers and of the community, but not in a way which will penalise those people who are required to work certain hours.

SPEECH.PARA: We hear the suggestion that trade unions should not be in existence. Only today I heard an employer state that the ideal situation for employers would be for trade unions to cease to exist. That man is having a foolish dream. There will always be a recognised role for labour and for capital. That is not to say that trade unions will always play a confrontationist role. Certain stages of history have required such a role to be played because of the terrible way in which employers exploited workers, so that they were forced to take such confrontationist action. Unions have changed their attitude and are seeking, in an equitable way, to cooperate with employers in order to create, as I say, a higher level of productivity in the interests of the community. Not all unions have had the ability or the resources to work this out and to put forward ideas which, when looked at in conjunction with employers' ideas, can ensure that a final compromise can be reached.

Those people who see unionists as bogy people should look at the trade union movement as a group of citizens who are represented through a formal structure who could well be convinced, in an equitable situation, to cooperate more and more with those employers who have a reasonable attitude to their community responsibilities and to the people who work for them. Of course, this does not require the creation of enterprise unions. Certainly, I agree that the amalgamation of trade unions is vitally important to the future of this country and to our prosperity. There should be one union in each workplace. But that same union should be nationwide in order to provide facilities so that workers will be able to negotiate with employers in an enterprise situation.

In answer to a question I asked during an Estimates committee hearing the other night, one of the officers from the Department of Industrial Relations made it very clear that even within the current Act there is provision for voluntary agreements-agreements that can be mutually agreed between the employer and the union or unions. A number of those are already registered. They are virtually enterprise agreements which have the award as a base and which include some other agreements. In some cases they move away from the award and become enterprise agreements. There is no problem under the current industrial relations system, the current union structure and the current employers structure. But the development of enterprise unions would take away the right of workers to be properly represented, to have made available to them the expert advice they need to negotiate their wages and conditions properly, to look at better ways of managing enterprises and to assert their democratic right to have a say at the workplace.

Trade unions introduced the idea of the 4 per cent trade-off. It gave a wage increase which was mutually acceptable to unions and employers. Recently they also developed the proposal for a 6 per cent increase in exchange for award restructuring. There is no doubt that the award restructuring will be beneficial to this country. I make it clear that my understanding is that there will not be trade-offs in relation to that restructuring. That restructuring will provide the sort of award structure that will give the opportunity for the best possible, efficient use of labour in an industry or enterprise, which will reduce labour costs and which will also enable people to produce quality products on time, which is very important to this country.

The sort of goodwill and trust that can be developed in this process is worth hundreds of millions of dollars to industry. Employers would be selling themselves short if they suggest that there should be trade-offs, if they try to destroy some of the hard-won gains that the trade union movement has made. Those gains are considered to represent the standard in this country and in other countries. Award restructuring is vitally important and it should not be sabotaged by unthinking, foolish employers who seek too much as a short term trade-off instead of looking for good faith, trust and a fairly efficient development of better working practices.

In conclusion, I mention that the Trade Union Training Authority has been playing a very important role in restructuring.
