It has been of concern to some Opposition members and some people in the community that employers do not have the opportunity to talk to trade unionists in order to put their side of the case, particularly in regard to restructuring. I know that when there was talk of a need to change the approach taken in certain industries, employers were invited to lecture trade union officials, shop stewards and opinion leaders in trade unions to explain what they were about, what they hoped to achieve and what they were prepared to agree to in terms of workers' reward, and what employers needed in terms of profits and financing in order to invest in research and development, new machinery and better technology. We need a balanced view. I think such consultations help to create it.

Those in the trade union movement need clearly to understand the meaning of equity. We need to accommodate the workers' right to strike while gradually working towards the elimination of the reasons for friction. Trust is vitally important. So long as wealth is created, there will be disputes. It is the manner in which such disputes are resolved that is important. All Australians want to have access to health care, education, excellent transport and communications systems, decent living standards, a continually improving social wage and the provision of assistance to other countries that are worse off than ourselves-that is, foreign aid. They want Australia to play a role in international forums and seek to reach a state of genuine world peace, without which it is not possible for anybody in this country, be they involved in the labour or capital areas, to reach the sorts of goals that we mutually want to achieve, and some goals about which there may be some conflict in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened quite intently to what the previous speaker, Senator Burns, had to say on the current economic situation. I was certainly glad that towards the end of his delivery he finally arrived at the situation in the twentieth century. Today we are debating the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1989-90, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90 and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1989-90. I enter this debate concerned about the way in which this country is proceeding towards a total disaster.

SPEECH.PARA: As we stood here last year we were amazed at the record interest rates that were around at the time: housing rates stood at about 14 1/2 per cent with the prime rate at 15.75 per cent. The Government told us it would reduce the interest rates and that we could not suffer interest rates of those dimensions for any length of time. Here we stand now with a 17 per cent-if not higher-housing interest rate and with a 21 per cent business rate. We stand here with a foreign debt at a record level of $108 billion, up from $23 billion at the end of the Fraser era. We stand here with an inflation rate of 8.3 per cent and rising. We stand here with a second downgrading of our credit rating which was announced just this week. What has happened to this country in the last 12 months, let alone--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a lot better than it was under your Government.
—I will come to Senator Cook's remark in a minute. What has happened to this country in the last 12 months, let alone in the last six years?
—You had double-digit unemployment and double-digit inflation.

—Has Senator Cook finished interjecting? This country used to be regarded as a land of opportunities, the lucky country, as Senator Burns told us, rich in natural resources. Those resources were developed during the Liberal governments of the 1950s and 1960s and the benefits were reaped in the 1970s and 1980s. The benefits from those resources started to run down badly with the advent of this Government. What are the reasons for this decline? Amongst other things, it is because this Government has allowed the decline in incentive for Australians to work and progress. It is one thing to work but it is another to progress. The Government has brought about this decline in many ways including a too heavy taxation regime which punishes endeavour by bracket creep, the slaughter of the small business group by the imposition of capital gains tax and by having to take on more and more load from high interest rates and charges, the continuation of work practices such as those involved with coastal shipping and the waterfront which have put costs beyond all reason, and the heavier reliance on social security as an option to working.
—That is just not true.

—That is definitely true. I will give Senator Cook the reasons for my statement as I come to them in my speech, if he will be patient. These are issues that we will deal with when we come to government. They are spelt out in our Economic Action Plan. Let us look at some of these aspects and where they have led us. Let us look at the issues of the waterfront and coastal shipping. As I said, I listened quite intently to Senator Burns earlier. I have listened intently to what this Government has had to say in the last few weeks when it has been acting in the pilots strike. Yet we have the continuing rorts and rip-offs of the waterfront. I happen to be in an industry that cops the end cost of those rorts.
—Your mob never did a single thing about it.

—There might not have been quite so much going on at the time. The actions on the waterfront have certainly been encouraged by the Government. This Government, despite the report of the Inter-State Commission, has done nothing to smash the outmoded work practices that exist. The only promise that the Government has made to date has been to saddle the Australian taxpayer with an expense of $600m to pay off waterside workers who have abused the situation perpetually.

SPEECH.PARA: A few weeks ago during the pilots dispute a remark came from an honourable senator on the other side of the Senate-I wish I could remember who made it-that we are only interested in people earning over $50,000 a year. I remember that I too made a remark at the time that that figure applies to the grain handlers in Newcastle who earn $70,000 a year for a 25-hour working week, even though they probably do not actually work those hours. Coastal shipping is in exactly the same position. Nothing has been done to encourage competition in that area. The Government is talking about putting competition into the airlines system and taking action to smash the Australian Federation of Air Pilots. Yet it will allow the coastal shipping situation to remain exactly the same as it has been for years.

I refer to rail transport. There has been some improvement in this direction especially in the State of Western Australia. I believe there has also been improvement in rail transport in the eastern States but nowhere near enough to bring the efficiency level to where it should be. This Government's policies have maintained the inefficient waterfront system with record costs to ship grain out or to handle other products being shipped into Australia and the inefficiency of the rail system to enable the transport of goods in a fast and efficient method and at a reasonable cost across Australia. What has the Government done to address these issues? The only mode of transport that has achieved any efficiency of late has been the road transport system saddled, as it may be, with certain penalties under this Government. In its own way that situation has led to the fiasco of the volume of freight carriers on our main roads at the moment. Because of the inefficient coastal shipping system and the inefficient rail system, our road systems are being overloaded. With the distances in Australia-after all, the distance from one side of Australia to the other is further than that from London to Moscow-there should be no way in the world, no way imaginable, that road transport should be able to compete with rail. Yet at present it does and it beats it hands down. That is the reason that there are more and more transporters on the road.

I know the road transport industry pretty well, as I have been involved in it for most of my life. The road transport system should principally be used in areas where there are no rail facilities. Also, coastal shipping could be used to transport goods. Of course, road transport must operate between Alice Springs and Darwin, and there is the Perth to the Pilbara route, although in that case coastal shipping should be able to help. However, even though other modes of transport are available the tendency is to transport more and more by road. There is no way in the world that so many trucks should be crossing the Nullarbor as they do and we should not have so many trucks driving between Sydney and Melbourne. I understand that this involves some 400 trucks a night.

The trucks are not speeding any more now than they were five years ago. From my own experience I believe that they have slowed down in the past five years. However, the number of accidents continues to increase. This is occurring for two reasons. As I have already pointed out, a number of vehicles have increased loadings. Also, through the natural progression of an affluent society the number of cars on the road is building up. The number of trucks is also increasing and the two do not mix very well.

Another reason why roads are becoming unsafe is that they are being increasingly pounded with the increased number of trucks driving on them every night and every day. The level of road funding provided by the Government is not sufficient, having regard to the increasing volume of road traffic over so many years. Accepting that we have these inefficient transport systems in relation to coastal shipping and rail transport, with the emphasis going back onto roads, one would think that the Government would increase the level of road funding. However, what has the Government done? In the past nearly five years the Government has kept road funding quite static, which means in real terms that road funding has decreased by some 36 per cent. Certain figures have been thrown around, but I believe it is between 36 per cent and 40 per cent.

I know the roads in Western Australia pretty well, and I know that the standard is decreasing. The Great Eastern Highway, the Great Northern Highway and the Albany Highway have taken a pounding in the past few years. About three weeks ago I was stuck in Canberra for a weekend and rather than spend it in the city I decided to hire a car and I went out and had a look at some of the agricultural areas of New South Wales and also parts of Victoria. The state of the roads in New South Wales is unbelievable and this is also the case in parts of northern Victoria.

They are in such a state that one would have to say that the Western Australian roads are very good, if one compared them on that basis. I am talking about miles and miles of main highways in New South Wales and Victoria. The off-highways do not get so much of a pounding. One finds corrugations in the bitumen and in many cases one comes across a square of about 10 metres by 3 metres-say, half the road-which has been simply carved out with a front-end loader, filled with gravel and rolled to the best extent possible. With the present funding program I cannot see how we will ever catch up with proper road maintenance.

The increased number of road transports on the roads, due to the inefficiency of the other transport systems, is the reason why Australian roads are becoming more dangerous by the day. I believe that road transports should be used only where other bulk transport is not available. Containerisation has been with us now for at least 25 years, and with the modern rail linkages, carriages and locomotives there is no reason at all for the present amount of road transport traffic between the capital cities.

I can see no reason why we cannot have even faster trains. They could probably use double-decker containers, even though the second container might have to be a special one for heights. These sorts of facilities could be used for goods that have to be transported between two cities or two destinations in a hurry. For goods that have to be transported from one side of the country to another in not such a hurry we could make a lot better use of coastal shipping facilities of some sort, using containerisation. I am afraid that we have missed our opportunity there because of what has happened in relation to coastal shipping and on the waterfront.

As I have said, in looking at the costings in relation to the various modes of transport, there is no way in the world that road transport should be able to compete. Further, the rougher roads mean that transporters are faced with increasing costs for the upkeep of their vehicles. These costs relate to the sorts of roads that vehicles must travel on, even bitumen roads. With the increasing costs of upkeep of their vehicles, road transporters have to do more and more trips in a shorter and shorter time to enable them to meet those costs. The result is an overloading of the roads such as we have at present and this has resulted in the recent spate of road accidents.

I now refer to the Government's propensity to close up resources. We used to be the lucky country, the land of opportunities, where everyone could do well provided that they worked. Today we need even more export income, but what is the Government doing? Why are we closing more and more avenues of resources? Mining at Coronation Hill, in Kakadu, has been postponed for a very expedient reason. However, following the election we will be in government and things will be different. Further, there has been the removal of logging in certain parts of Australia, in Queensland and Tasmania, particularly. About 18 months ago I asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) a question about Shark Bay, and he denied that there was ever any idea of locking up pastoral ground in that area. Of course, we know what happened to that. So, more and more resource areas have been closed off, while in other cases more and more obstructions are being put in the way of production.

Australians must be given an incentive to work and prosper. This Government is doing everything in reverse. We have bracket creep, capital gains tax and tax on superannuation. I heard a Government senator talk about what this Government has done with superannuation. I will tell the Senate what this Government has done with superannuation: it has found another milking cow.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has brought it within the reach of ordinary wage earners. Fifty per cent of the population did not have it before.

—The Government may have done something to decrease that percentage. I am the first to admit that over the years governments of all persuasions have neglected superannuation. I study the superannuation systems of other countries when I go overseas. Australia has made giant strides in the last 15 years.
—Yes, thanks to a Labor government.

—Yes, it has learnt how to milk the superannuation scheme. The capital gains tax is now five years old. And it is starting to bite. Many businesses start off as husband and wife shows. They develop trade in order to sell the business to enable them to move into something else. Under this Government's capital gains tax, which will be reversed as soon as we are in government, if a roadhouse or a sandwich bar is sold, 49 per cent of the gain from the effort is paid to the Government's coffers, with the result that many such business people are not able to move on to a bigger business or have to borrow the money to do so. It is time that Australians recognised their business men and women in the way they recognise their sports stars and did not treat them as speculators, which is exactly what is done by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Several weeks ago there was an article in one of the Sydney papers about the New South Wales Government bringing in a Bill to require members of the State Parliament to disclose their interests. I have no beef about members of parliament or senators disclosing their interests. I wish I had kept the paper but from memory the headline said that the whistle had been blown on members of parliament because, by having to disclose what had been accumulated, a member of parliament had been found to have three houses. Is that a criminal offence in the eyes of the average Australian these days? The particular member that the paper referred to happened to be an independent member. The newspaper lauded the fact that members of parliament would have to disclose their interests. The newspaper made out that to own property was something to be ashamed of.

While I was lying on my back last week I had time to reflect on things, including whether I was going to get back here eventually. I read Senator Macklin's proposal for senators and members to declare what they have. As I said, I have no beef about declaring interests. Senator Macklin said, `Fancy anyone owning gold shares being able to vote on the gold tax issue'. Let me take the argument a little further. Let us see how many members of parliament would be left if we excluded all those who had interests. I presume Senator Macklin has children in tertiary education. If they are in line for a tertiary allowance, or whatever it is called these days, Senator Macklin should not be allowed to vote on that issue. If members of parliament have a car and drive for reward or pleasure, they should not be able to vote on road funding. If we take the argument through to its conclusion-and this Government is trying to paint the picture that it is a criminal offence to accumulate property-nobody here will be able to vote on anything.

I now refer to the incentives for people to work in Australia. I am talking about those who are capable of working but who choose not to. I respect the wishes of those people who do not wish to work but, if they wish to spend their time on the beach in Broome, or in the Margaret River area, or on Bondi Beach, or if they wish to travel with their girlfriends to Bali or hitch-hike across Australia, that is their prerogative; but they should not expect us to pay for them. That is something we will change when we are in government. Our policy will weed out the friends of this Government-the social security cheats. At the end of nine months on the dole they will be assessed to see whether they belong to a special category and, if they do not they had better start looking for a job. Looking for work means looking for work where there is work, not looking where there is no work. Senator Cooney earlier said-and I respect what he has to say-something about old people and people on invalid pensions. We are not after the old person; we are after the young and able bludger. Anyone genuinely on an invalid pension-if a person has permanent brain damage, for instance-will continue to receive assistance. As the Senate knows, I am in the building game. I personally know dozens of people who are on the invalid pension but who are still working under the subcontract system. Under our leadership they will be weeded out. If they do not fill the bill, they will be made to accept their responsibilities.

There are many unemployed people in the cities, in the beach resorts and in the surfing spots while at the same time jobs cannot be filled in the countryside, where 85 per cent of Australia's export income comes from. They are not heavy jobs. There are jobs as shire clerks, as ordinary clerks in shires, as shop assistants, as teachers, and as swimming pool operators. Those jobs cannot be filled, yet the bludgers are on the beaches. I will give the Senate the small example of a migrant couple who run a roadhouse in my home town. They have not been in Australia very long. They have been able to educate their two children in tertiary institutions. They were looking for an assistant to help them in their cafeteria. They approached a girl in the town who they knew had been on the dole for a long time. They said, `Would you like to work for us?'. The girl's answer was: `Do you think I will give up my dole to work in your greasy cafeteria?'. When one lodges a job with the Commonwealth Employment Service for, say, machinery operators, one immediately gets 10 phone calls. A bloke is picked to start and then he will find all the excuses not to start. He simply uses that to enable him to put it down as a place where he looked for work but could not get it.

Country people provide export income and pay tax to keep the dole bludgers in their comforts. Australians need to get their priorities right and recognise what people in the countryside do. There are many things that the Government could do in the immediate future to get things moving. Senator Richardson, in his latest outburst in the Land, said he intended to depopulate marginal areas. I hope he has plenty of money ready because he has many people to buy out just in the areas of Western Australia.

I finish on the note that, when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that no child need live in poverty by 1990, it was a twist on what he actually said which was that no child would live in poverty by 1990. It will no doubt surprise you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I agree with the Prime Minister, but it is not by his machinations that we have come to that situation. There has been no need for any child in Australia to live in poverty since the end of the Great Depression. It is only because the Government has let the country run down that we have even to talk in terms of having no child living in poverty by 1990. Let us get back to the priorities of Australia and get Australia moving again. That is what we will do when we come to government in the next few months.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I will address my remarks to the problems of pharmacists. It is now one and three-quarter hours before midnight-literally and metaphorically-as it is one and three-quarter hours before the demise of Australia's pharmacists and chemists. It is appropriate today to address some of the problems, including the inevitable bankruptcies, that are facing a great many of them. Tomorrow morning, something like a third of Australia's chemists will be facing ruin, devastation. The Government is removing $30m from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. In every State in Australia the pharmacists will not sleep tonight. They will be worried about their futures, that of their families and how they will meet their commitments and keep their children in school. They will have a sleepless night tonight as they toss and turn, wondering what they have done to offend the Government and why it should seek to make such a massive attack on them.

A number of pharmacists in Queensland will face ruin. About 80 country towns have only one pharmacist. If those pharmacies fail in those towns, whole towns will be ruined because a town without a pharmacy is incomplete. People will do their shopping in bigger towns and we will see the death of many Queensland rural towns. I refer to towns like Goomeri, Blackwater and a number of others. It is not only the pharmacies that have been put at risk; whole towns have been put at risk because when a major sector of trade, such as a pharmacy, is removed from a town which has one butcher, one pub, and one garage, people will bypass that town. Purchasers will do their business in another area.

The Federal Government has admitted that it wants to shut down one-third of Australia's 5,600 pharmacies. Since January 1988 there has been a sustained attack on and systematic destruction of the community pharmacy by severely reducing incomes. This has not just come on in the last week or the last two months. It has been happening since January 1988. In January last year the wholesaler margin was reduced by 5 per cent from 15 per cent to 10 per cent. That was designed to lower the wholesaler's profit. Of course, it never did so. It just cut off the margin of the pharmacist. The wholesalers passed on their increased costs to the pharmacists. Pharmaceuticals that used to cost $100 now cost the chemist $105.

Six months after that, the pharmacists were advised to double the number of items included in a standard prescription. It could quite genuinely be argued that that was a cost saving, but it also had a massive effect on pharmacists. They now prescribe half the number of prescriptions they prescribed previously and their shop trade has been affected. I do not think that Senator Tate would understand that people picking up their pharmaceutical requirements from a pharmacist generally also buy something in the merchandise area. So that has had another effect on the incomes of Australian pharmacists.

In January this year the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal recommended that the handling fee for pharmaceutical benefits scheme drugs be reduced by 10c from $2.64 to $2.54. The pharmacists took that recommendation to court and won the case. Subsequently, the decision was challenged and their win was reduced. But the most devastating blow delivered to pharmacists by the Government was its acceptance of the Remuneration Tribunal's decision to abolish the 25 per cent mark-up. While the rest of Australian workers have received a 6 per cent pay increase, Australian pharmacists have had their incomes reduced by 23 per cent, which represents an average loss of approximately $27,000.

I fail to understand, and I fail to see how anyone of average intelligence can understand, how the Labor Party Government can expect people to trade with no mark-up. Senator Tate and Senator McKiernan are reasonable people. They should understand that it is quite impossible for a trader-whether it be a chemist, a hardware store, a grocery store or any other merchandiser-to purchase a product at a certain price, wholesale it at the same price and continue to stay in business. It is so elementary that everyone in the Labor Party-whether or not he or she has ever been in business or in any other industry-should find it easy to understand. It is just not possible to run a shop, to pay the rent on that shop, to pay the insurance on the shop, to pay the wages for the employees of the shop and to pay all of the other sundry expenses that retailers incur and sell products for exactly the same prices at which they were bought. I challenge anyone in the Labor Party to give me an intelligent explanation of how it is possible to survive when one is buying a product and selling it at exactly the same price.

I would have thought that a reasonable gesture on behalf of the Labor Party would have been to go to the chemists-if this is the course that it wanted to pursue-and to say to them, `We are going to reduce your mark-up and we are going to pay you a small service fee on the products you sell'. It would have been reasonable for the Government to go to the chemists, and offer to buy their stock and then sell it back to them on consignment. In other words, if a pharmacy carried $70,000 or $80,000 worth of pharmaceutical benefits stock, the Government could purchase that stock and sell it back on invoice, paying the pharmacists a small fee. That would have been within the realms of possibility to allow the pharmacists to survive, but the Government has not done that.

The Government has expected pharmacists to pay 23 per cent interest rates. That is what small businesses are paying. It is no wonder that people in small business are going out backwards. Pharmacists are taking a risk when they buy stock because they are outlaying the money that they have earned. If drugs remain on pharmacy shelves past their expiry date, pharmacists lose that stock. Alternatively, a doctor who is prescribing a particular drug may have a change of heart and will prescribe another drug for the same type of ailment, thereby making the first stock redundant. The risk is all the pharmacists' and none of the Government's.

The expenses of retailers are increasing dramatically. The pharmacist is unable to meet those expenses. As a result, he is going to be even less likely to be able to meet his commitments. During the past two or three months I have spoken to many pharmacists-I have been on the phone to them continually-who are frantically trying to obtain some sort of a decision, some sort of a turnaround, from the Government. Their pleas are falling on deaf ears and they are receiving no satisfaction. I cannot understand why the Government is determined to adopt this course of action. The pharmacists are frantic. They are not used to dealing with people such as those in the Labor Government; they are used to dealing with old ladies, weighing babies and talking to people. All of a sudden they have become involved in a confrontation with the Government.

The Government knows that pharmacists have a high social rating and great credibility in the community. The Government has set out on an orchestrated campaign to discredit the community perception of pharmacists. It has been a sustained and cleverly mounted attack, obviously undertaken with the benefit of research. I can imagine Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd polling Australian citizens on how they regard pharmacists and then coming back to the Government and saying, `Look, you have a problem there. These people are held in high regard. The only way you are going to survive is to discredit them'. We see the mean Labor machine going into attack against those innocent victims-people who are not used to bloody, dirty, political fighting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight about the historic endorsement of Mr Ray Leslie as the Australian Labor Party (ALP) candidate for the seat of Parkes in the House of Representatives. SPEECH.PARA: I have also been moved to speak in this adjournment debate because of a range of misleading newspaper articles which have appeared regarding Mr Bob Liddle, who is the recently dumped Country Liberal Party (CLP) candidate for the seat of the Northern Territory. Over the past few months it has been variously claimed that Mr Liddle is the first Aborigine to gain major party pre-selection for the House of Representatives, or is the first Aborigine to contest a House of Representatives seat, or is the only Aboriginal candidate to be contesting a House of Representatives seat in the next Federal election. I believe that all these claims are wrong.

Let me give the Senate some examples of the more absurd claims about Mr Liddle's candidature that have been made in the press. The first comes from the Australian newspaper of 13 February 1989 in an article under the heading `CLP fields its first Aboriginal candidate'. The article states:
An Alice Springs businessman-
that is, Mr Liddle-
has become the first Aborigine to gain preselection by a major party for a House of Representatives seat.
On 18 February this year, the Melbourne Age, in an article headed `Aborigine expects to win marginal Northern Territory seat' stated:
An Alice Springs Aborigine is confident of winning a marginal Northern Territory seat at the next Federal election.

Mr Bob Liddle, 48, is the first Aborigine to contest a seat in the lower house. He won preselection as the Country-Liberal Party candidate last Saturday. Mr Liddle says he went in with eight out of 47 votes and came out with a majority.
Then on 4 March 1989 in the Australian, in a very long article by Greg Sheridan called `The candidate with a difference', the following appeared:
. . . Bob Liddle has made history by becoming the first Aborigine to be preselected by a major party for a winnable seat in the House of Representatives.
Just two weeks ago, he was chosen by the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party (CLP) to contest the seat of the Northern Territory in the next federal election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Redneck stuff.
—He does say that. Let me quote him in a moment. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: The dumped Country Liberal Party candidate for the House of Representatives, Bob Liddle, said today he would renominate for the Northern Territory seat.
Mr Liddle, the first Aborigine to gain major party pre-selection for the Lower House, was dumped at a special meeting of the CLP's central council last night.

The only Aboriginal candidate for the forthcoming election for the House of Representatives has been dumped by the Northern Territory's ruling Country Liberal Party (CLP) . . .

In The Weekend Australian it was reported that Mr Liddle was the only Aboriginal candidate for the forthcoming federal election. This is not correct. Mr Ray Leslie, an Aborigine, is the endorsed ALP candidate for the NSW seat of Parkes.

I recall Mr Galarrwuy Yunupingu's nomination-I am sure Senator Tambling will recall it-in the seat of the Northern Territory in 1980, when he stood as an independent and secured 5.59 per cent of the vote. SPEECH.PARA: The Albanian community in Australia feels very strongly about this matter. It is a matter that concerns them greatly.
